As the test answers consist only of ‘had/donated’ and ‘would have/would donate’ variants, the test sentence ‘If I ________ (to have) one billion dollars I ________ (to donate) a half to charity.’ describes an unlikely situation. It means that ‘I don’t have one billion dollars, that is why I can’t donate a half to charity.’ The speaker is still thinking about the future possibility, but it is imaginary – I imagine that I could donate some money to charity, but it is unlikely. In this case the question between the first and the second conditional is often a question of the speaker’s attitude to the situation.As for the test ANSWER, we are to choose ANSWER 2 (had/would donate).

Task: "Stephanie: ""I'm doing my homework now""."
a: Stephanie said that she was doing her homework now.
b: Stephanie said that she had been doing her homework then.
c: Stephanie said that she was doing her homework then.
d: Stephanie said that she had been doing her homework now.
comment: We change the Present Continuous to the Past Continuous in Reported Speech. Also we change some time expressions: now - then

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: Bad Bellingen is a nice small town in Germany.
b: Bad Bellingen is a small nice town in Germany.
c: In Germany Bad Bellingen is a nice small town.
d: In Germany Bad Bellingen is a small nice town.
comment: There is a certain word order in statements with the Present Simple Tense: Subject - Auxiliary - Object. When we need to use many adjectives in one sentence, they should be placed in the following order: Opinion - Size - Age - Shape - Colour - Origin - Material. 'Nice' is an opinion adjective and 'small' refers to size.

Task: I ate _ plum and went out.
comment: We use the article 'a' with singular countable nouns also to show the quantity - only one.

Task: I like to watch thrillers, but now I ______ (to watch) a comedy.
comment: The adverb 'now' means that the action is happening at this certain moment. So, in this case we should always use the Present Continuous Tense. This Tense is formed: Auxiliary (am/is/are) + Verb-ing.

Task: First of all, we visited the British Museum, then we went to Hyde Park and last we ____________ (to relax) in a restaurant.
comment: We use the past tense to talk about something that happened once in the past - a completed action in a time before now. Duration is not important: Sally watched TV last night.; Did you play tennis at weekends?. It can also be used for actions taking place one after another or in the middle of another action: She entered a cafe, took off her coat, sat down and took the menu.; Roby fell off the tree and her friends took her to a doctor.In the test sentence ‘First of all, we visited the British Museum, then we went to Hyde Park and last we______ (to relax) in a restaurant.’. we need to form the past form of the regular verb ‘relax’. For regular verbs, we add -ed to the base form of the verb (work – worked) or -d if the verb already ends in e (move – moved). Therefore, we are to choose ANSWER 2 (relaxed).

Task: Ok, I’ve decided! I _________ (to go) to the gallery tomorrow.
comment: We use the Future Simple Tense when we talk about common actions and facts which will happen in the future. We can use the Future Simple (will and shall) to express immediate intentions and decisions: Will you come for dinner on Saturday? If we chose ANSWER 3 (will go), it will sound like the speaker’s immediate decision.

Task: This work ____________ (to complete) tomorrow.
comment: When we don't know who carries out the action, or it is obvious or unimportant to us, we use the Passive voice. In this sentence we speak about the action which will be completed in the future: Will Be + Past Participle.

Task: Susan is 10 and she ______________ skate yet.
comment: The modal verb 'can' is used when we speak about the ability in the Present.

Task: Rachel is ___________ (to stay in anticipation) summer holiday.
comment: Phrasal verbs are verbs that consist of a verb and a particle and/or a preposition. Phrasal verbs are typical of spoken English or informal writing, e.g. letters to friends and articles in popular journalism. They cannot be understood based upon the meanings of the individual parts in isolation, thus, their meanings are unpredictable. The phrasal verb 'to look forward to' means 'to stay in anticipation'.

Task: Choose  two forms of the verb 'to steal' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO STEAL - STOLE - STOLEN

Task: Nicki left Peter and returned to Seattle. Now she lives by ________ .
comment: By herself' means 'alone'. We cannot use any other form of a pronoun in this phrase.

Task: Chris found a ________ ________ _________ (cute/little/grey) kitten.
comment: It is very unusual to have more than three adjectives in front of a noun. But if it is so, the most usual sequence of adjectives is the following: 1. general opinion (good, bad, lovely, strange, nice, important,etc.), 2. specific opinion (a) food: tasty; delicious; (b) furniture, buildings: comfortable; uncomfortable;(c) people, animals: clever; friendly), 3. size (big, tall), 4. physical quality (thin, rough, untidy), 5. shape (round, square), 6. age (old, babyish), 7. colour (green, pastel), 8. origin (Japanese, northern), 9. material(metal, wood, plastic), 10. type (general-purpose, U-shaped, bedroom, four-sided), 11. purpose (folding, swinging, work, racing).Therefore, in the test sentence ‘Chris found a _______ _______ ________ (cute/little/grey) kitten.’ we should choose ANSWER 3: a cute (1. general opinion) little (3. size) grey (7. colour) kitten.

Task: His team plays football ________.
comment: We use adverbs to describe time, degree, manner, etc. In other words adverbs help us get more information about the action or the place (where, when, how, how often, etc.) Many adverbs are formed from adding '-ly' or '-ily' to the adjective.

Task: He shook hands with a man _______ is a mayor.
comment: We use 'that' and 'who' for people in relative clauses.  'Whose' and 'whom' are used as objects.

Task: Sarah always puts the blame ____ someone else.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them. In the test sentence ‘Sarah always puts the blame ____ someone else.’ we need to choose the preposition that is used after the noun ‘blame’ that means ‘the situation in which people say or think that someone or something did something wrong or is responsible for something bad happening’. We can use three prepositions after the noun ‘blame’: (1) ‘for’ (I always get the blame for his mistakes!); (2) ‘on’ (He stole the money but he’s trying to put the blame on me.); (3) ‘onto’ (It’s no use trying to shift the blame onto other people.). Among the test answers we can choose ANSWER 4: ‘on’.

Task: John is ill. He must stay ____ bed.
comment: It is correct to say 'in bed'

Task: I'm not keen ______ yoga.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'keen on'

Task: How many natural _________ (a phenomenon) do you know?
comment: There are many nouns which have Greek or Latin origin. As a rule, they keep own endings: A PHENOMENON - TWO PHENOMENA

Task: It's too dark, I can't see __________ .
comment: We use the pronoun 'something' to refer to things in affirmative sentences, while 'anything' in negative ones. 'Any' and 'some' are pronouns which don't relate to the meaning of the sentence.
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: If Mike _________ (to return) early we ________ (to have) dinner with him.
comment: When we speak about probable situations in the present or future we use Conditional 1: If-clause (if + Present Simple) - Main Clause (future/modal + present without 'to') or If-clause (if + Present Simple) - Main Clause (future + HAVE TO, OUGHT TO, BE TO + present without 'to').

Task: "Carla: ""I've forgotten my e-mail password""."
a: Carla said that she has forgotten her e-mail password.
b: Carla said that she forgot her e-mail password.
c: Carla said that she had forgotten her e-mail password.
d: Carla said that she had been forgetting her e-mail password.
comment: We change the Present Perfect to the Past Perfect in Reported Speech.

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: The Olympics take place every four years.
b: Every four years take place the Olympics.
c: The Olympics take every four years place.
d: Take place the Olympics every four years.
comment: There is a certain word order in statements: Subject - Predicate - Object. The phrase 'take place' shouldn't be divided.

Task: Can you show me _ Volga on the map?
comment: The is used before names of rivers.

Task: Bill and Richard _________ (to be) friends for many ages.
comment: The action in this sentence started in the Past and continues in the Present. It means that Bill and Richard are still friends. In this case we should use the Present Perfect Tense:  has/have + Verb (-ed/Irregular)

Task: David Beckham _____________ (to play) for Manchester United from 1993 to 2003.
comment: Past simple is used to talk about finished actions and time. And in the test sentence ‘David Beckham ________ (to play) for Manchester United from 1993 to 2003.’ we are given the time-marker ‘from… to’ that we use to say when a past situation started and finished. Therefore, we are to choose ANSWER 1 (played).

Task: I'm so tired of this town. I ____________ (to move) to Paris.
comment: If we have a plan, ambition or intention to do something for the future we use 'be going to’. If we choose ANSWER 1 (am going to move), we create the context about the speaker’s future intentions that have been decided but have not been fully planned (referring to the past decision) that is expressed by the construction ‘be going to’.

Task: Berlin _______________ (to found) in the 12th century.
comment: When we don't know who carries out the action, or it is obvious or unimportant to us, we use the Passive voice. The Passive is formed: BE + Past Participle. In this sentence the action took place at a certain time in the past, so we use the Past Simple Passive.

Task: __________ you make me a cup of coffee, please?
comment: We use the modal verb 'could' when we ask somebody to do something.

Task: Melanie has to _________ (to go in front of) because she is the leader in her squad.
comment: Phrasal verbs are verbs that consist of a verb and a particle and/or a preposition. Phrasal verbs are typical of spoken English or informal writing, e.g. letters to friends and articles in popular journalism. They cannot be understood based upon the meanings of the individual parts in isolation, thus, their meanings are unpredictable. The phrasal verb 'to go ahead' means 'to be in front of'.

Task: Choose  two forms of the verb 'to swim' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO SWIM - SWAM - SWUM

Task: Jake said that he saw Jessica Alba ______ in the street.
comment: We use here 'herself' to show the importance of an object. In this sentence we mean that the fact of meeting a certain person - Jessica Alba - was very important for Jake. 'Himself' does not relate to the meaning.

Task: I think this street is ________ in the town.
comment: When we compare a person or a thing with more than one person or one thing we use the superlative form of adjectives. If we use a one-syllable adjective '-est' to it.

Task: The rain was falling ________.
comment: We use adverbs to describe time, degree, manner, etc. In other words adverbs help us get more information about the action or the place (where, when, how, how often, etc.) Many adverbs are formed from adding '-ly' or '-ily' to the adjective.

Task: The singer, ______ I like a lot, is Corey Taylor.
comment: What' is a question word, it cannot be used here. We use 'which' for animals and objects. 'Whose' refers to possession and 'whom' is used as an object.

Task: Caroline should understand that she takes responsibility ____ what is happening in her work and life.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'responsibility for'

Task: Mike was _____ the bus when I texted him.
comment: It is correct to say 'on the bus'

Task: Your jacket is similar ______ mine.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'similar to'

Task: I can't remember all these __________ (a formula).
comment: There are many nouns which have Greek or Latin origin. As a rule, they keep own endings: A FORMULA - TWO FORMULAE. 'Formulas' also can be used.

Task: We haven't got _________ salt.
comment: Much' is used before uncountable nouns. 'Many', 'a few' - before countable. We use 'some' in positive sentences.
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: If I __________ (to win) an Olympic medal I __________ (to dedicate) it to my family.
comment: When we speak about imaginary situations which differ from real facts in the present we use Conditional 2: If-clause (if + Past Simple) - Main Clause (would/could + present without 'to'). The meaning of this sentence: in reality I'm not a sportsman, I only imagine

Task: "Dexter: ""I'll read this book next month""."
a: Dexter said that he would read that book the month after.
b: Dexter said that he would read that book next month.
c: Dexter said that he  read that book the month after.
d: Dexter said that he had read that book next month.
comment: We change the Future Simple to the Conditional in Reported Speech: will - would. Also we change time expressions: next month - the month after

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: My husband returns usually home at 7 p.m.
b: My husband usually returns home  at 7 p.m.
c: My husband returns home  at 7 p.m. usually.
d: My husband returns home at usually 7 p.m.
comment: The adverb goes after the auxiliary verb. But if there is no auxiliary verb in the sentence, the adverb should be placed before the main verb.

Task: New York is  _  city in the USA.
comment: We use the article 'a' with singular countable nouns when we talk about them in general.

Task: Don't disturb Tony! He ____________ (to write) a letter at the moment.
comment: The phrase 'at the moment' means that the action is happening at this certain moment, right now. So, in this case we should always use the Present Continuous Tense. This Tense is formed: am/is/are + Verb-ing.

Task: Jill wiped the table after supper, took a shower and ___________ (to go) to bed.
comment: When we talk about actions which happened one after another in the past we use the Past Simple Tense.

Task: Susan ________ (to go) to the birthday party this weekend. Sarah invited her a week ago.
comment: If we have decided to do something or arranged to do something in the near future we use 'be going to'.

Task: These shoes _______________ (to make) in Italy.
comment: When we don't know who carries out the action, or it is obvious or unimportant to us, we use the Passive voice. The Passive is formed: BE + Past Participle

Task: Don't run! The dog ______________ get furious.
comment: We use the modal verb 'may' when it is possible that something will happen.

Task: They _________ (to raise a child) two children.
comment: Phrasal verbs are verbs that consist of a verb and a particle and/or a preposition. Phrasal verbs are typical of spoken English or informal writing, e.g. letters to friends and articles in popular journalism. They cannot be understood based upon the meanings of the individual parts in isolation, thus, their meanings are unpredictable. The phrasal verb 'to bring up' means 'to raise a child'.

Task: Choose  two forms of the verb 'to take' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO TAKE - TOOK - TAKEN

Task: Is there _______ who can speak Italian?
comment: Everybody' and 'nobody' do not relate to the meaning of the sentence. 'Anybody' is used in interrogative sentences, while 'somebody' is used in affirmative sentences.

Task: Lily wants everything right now. She's too ________ .
comment: We should remember that the adjective 'patient' is used with the prefix 'im-'

Task: Ted passed the test _________.
comment: We use adverbs to describe time, degree, manner, etc. In other words adverbs help us get more information about the action or the place (where, when, how, how often, etc.) Many adverbs are formed from adding '-ly' or '-ily' to the adjective.

Task: He is playing with the boy, ______ gave him a balloon two days ago.
comment: We use 'who' for people in relative clauses when 'who' is a subject. 'Whose' and 'whom' are used as objects. We use 'which' to refer to animals and objects.

Task: John announced the best solution ____ our problem.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'solution to'

Task: I usually go to the GYM ____ Mondays and Thursdays.
comment: It is correct to say 'on Mondays'

Task: Your essay is full _____ mistakes.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'full of'

Task: There are a few _________ (an oasis) in deserts.
comment: There are many nouns which have Greek or Latin origin. As a rule, they keep own endings: AN OASIS - TWO OASES

Task: There are ________ books on the shelf.
comment: Many' is used before countable nouns. 'Much' and 'a little' - before uncountable. We use 'any' in negative sentences.
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: The police _________ (to arrest) her if they ________ (to catch) her.
comment: When we speak about probable situations in the present or future we use Conditional 1: If-clause (if + Present Simple) - Main Clause (future/modal + present without 'to') or If-clause (if + Present Simple) - Main Clause (future + HAVE TO, OUGHT TO, BE TO + present without 'to').

Task: "Teacher: ""Don't be so lazy""."
a: Teacher asked us did not to be so lazy.
b: Teacher asked us not to be so lazy.
c: Teacher asked us did not be so lazy.
d: Teacher asked us to be not so lazy.
comment: When we need to transform a request into Reported Speech we use an introductory verb + the to-infinitive: asked not + to be

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: You can show me the way to  Westminster Abbey?
b: Can show you me the way to  Westminster Abbey?
c: Can you show me the way to Westminster Abbey?
d: To Westminster Abbey you can show me the way?
comment: When we want to ask a question with a modal verb we must place it in the first place: Modal Verb - Subject - Predicate - Object. 'Can' is a modal verb, 'you' - a subject, 'show' - a predicate, 'me the way to the Westminster Abbey' - an object.

Task: My husband gave me _ twenty five roses.
comment: When we use numerals before nouns we don't use any article.

Task: Rachel __________ (to be) in Frankfurt since Sunday.
comment: The action in this sentence started in the Past (on Monday) and continues in the Present. It means that Rachel is still in Frankfurt. In this case we should use the Present Perfect Tense:  has/have + Verb (-ed/Irregular)

Task: Abraham Lincoln ______________ (to become) the 16th President of the United States in 1860.
comment: We use the Past Simple Tense when we talk about actions which happened at a definite time in the past.

Task: It's very cold today. I expect it ____________ (to snow) tomorrow.
comment: We use the Future Simple Tense when we make predictions about the future with the verbs 'expect, think, believe, etc.'

Task: The room _________ (to clean) tomorrow.
comment: When we don't know who carries out the action, or it is obvious or unimportant to us, we use the Passive voice. In this sentence we speak about the action which will be completed in the future: Will Be + Past Participle.

Task: Carol is very ill. She _____________ take medicines every day.
comment: We use the modal verb 'must' when we talk about duties or when it is necessary to do something.

Task: It's a great pity that Helen and Bob _______ (to separate)
comment: Phrasal verbs are verbs that consist of a verb and a particle and/or a preposition. Phrasal verbs are typical of spoken English or informal writing, e.g. letters to friends and articles in popular journalism. They cannot be understood based upon the meanings of the individual parts in isolation, thus, their meanings are unpredictable. The phrasal verb 'to break up' means 'to separate'.

Task: Choose  two forms of the verb 'to wake' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO WAKE - WOKE - WOKEN

Task: Lisa, do you want to give anybody these flowers? - No, I've bought them for _______ .
comment: When the same person is both the subject and the object in the sentence we place a reflexive pronoun after a verb or a preposition. 'Myself' is the right reflexive form of the personal pronoun 'I'. Other answers do not relate to the meaning.

Task: Jessy is being very ______ today!
comment: We should remember that the adjective 'polite' is used with the prefix 'im-'

Task: The dog was waiting for him ________.
comment: We use adverbs to describe time, degree, manner, etc. In other words adverbs help us get more information about the action or the place (where, when, how, how often, etc.) Many adverbs are formed from adding '-ly' or '-ily' to the adjective.

Task: Rachel told us the news, ______ we had already heard.
comment: We use 'which' or 'that' for things in relative clauses.  'Whose' and 'whom' are used as objects.

Task: Nelly has experience ____ accounting.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'experience in'

Task: I don't like to get up early ____ the morning.
comment: It is correct to say 'in the morning'

Task: I'm always short ______ time.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'short of'

Task: There are many ________ (a salmon) in these waters.
comment: There are some nouns which have the same form in the singular and in the plural: ONE SALMON - TWO SALMON

Task: I have _______ money left after shopping.
comment: A little' is used before uncountable nouns. 'Many', 'a few' and 'few' - before countable
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: If I _________ (to be) taller I _________ (to be) a model.
comment: When we speak about imaginary situations which differ from real facts in the present we use Conditional 2: If-clause (if + Past Simple) - Main Clause (would/could + present without 'to'). The meaning of this sentence: in reality I'm not a model

Task: "Jane: ""Mike plays the violin""."
a: Jane said that Mike played the violin.
b: Jane said that Mike had played the violin.
c: Jane said that Mike was playing the violin.
d: Jane said that Mike would play the violin.
comment: We change the Present Simple to the Past Simple in Reported Speech.

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
comment: The right word order in the wh-question is: Question Word - Auxiliary - Subject. 'What' is a question word, 'is' - an auxiliary verb, ' your favourite colour' - a subject.

Task: Everest is _ highest mountain in the world.
comment: We use 'the' with all kinds of nouns when we talk about definite and specific things. 'The' also before nouns mentioned for the second time. Here: we know that there is the only highest mountain in the world.

Task: Rob __________ (not / to finish) the task yet.
comment: The action in this sentence started at an unstated time in the Past and continues in the Present. It means that Rob is still doing the task. In this case we should use the Present Perfect Tense:  has/have + Verb (-ed/Irregular)

Task: I was sitting in the cafe when my phone __________ (to ring).
comment: In this case the first action was in progress when suddenly something interrupted it. For a longer action we use the Past Continuous Tense. The second action was shorter so we should use the Past Simple Tense. The verb 'to ring' is irregular: RING - RANG - RUNG

Task: Jerry is in Cardiff now. You ___________ (to see) him till Tuesday.
comment: We use the Future Simple Tense when we talk about common actions and facts which will happen in the future.

Task: The ballots ___________ (to count) several hours ago.
comment: When we don't know who carries out the action, or it is obvious or unimportant to us, we use the Passive voice. The Passive is formed: BE + Past Participle. In this sentence the action took place at a certain time in the past, so we use the Past Simple Passive.

Task: You are sometimes totally unbearable! You _____________ be more tolerant.
comment: We use the modal verb 'should' when we give advice or recommend something.

Task: You play chess very well, I think you should ________ (to take part in) the school competition.
comment: In this sentence we are given the definition of one of four phrasal verbs ‘to take part in’. The phrasal verb ‘go in for’ has some meanings: (1) ‘to do something regularly, or to enjoy something’ (I don’t go in for surfing much.); (2) (BrE) ‘to take part in a competition, or to take an examination’ (She went in for the exam.); (3) (BrE) ‘to choose something as a subject of study or as your career’ (I am sure that she’s planning to go in for politics.). The second meaning of this phrasal verb suits the test sentence, thus, we are to choose ANSWER 4 (go in for) in the test.

Task: Choose  two forms of the verb 'to write' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO WRITE - WROTE - WRITTEN

Task: Vicky, if someone sends a message answer _____ .
comment: When we need to refer to a person after 'someone', 'anyone' and 'no one' we use the personal pronoun 'they'. Here the pronoun has the position of the object. That is why we use the objective form - 'them'.

Task: This group of young people committed many _______ actions.
comment: In the test variants we are given the adjective ‘social’ with four prefixes dis-, un-, non-, anti-. The adjective ‘unsocial’ means ‘happening during days of the week or hours when most people do not have to work’ (Nobody wants to work unsocial hours.). The prefix ‘anti’ means ‘against, in opposition to, or opposite of’. The adjective ‘antisocial’ means (1) ‘harmful to society’ and (2) ‘often avoiding spending time with other people’. Its synonyms are ‘unfriendly’ and ‘cold’. There is even one more adjective ‘insocial’ that means ‘not sociable’.The words ‘dissociable’ and ‘non-sociable’ are nonce-words. Therefore, among the test variants we are to choose ANSWER 4 (antisocial).

Task: Peter always dresses _________.
comment: We use adverbs to add more information about a verb, an adjective, another adverb, a clause or a whole sentence. In the test sentence ‘Peter always dresses _________.’ we add more information about the verb ‘dress’.Adverbs have many different meanings and functions. They are especially important for indicating the time (when), manner (the way something happens or is done, how something happens), place (where), degree (how) and frequency (how often) of something. In the test we are given four variants: ‘smarty’, ‘smart’, ‘smartly’ and ‘smartful’ that have the same root morpheme ‘smart’ that has several meanings: (1) ‘stylish’; (2) ‘intelligent’; (3) ‘quick’; (4) ‘without respect’. As the test sentence is connected with clothes, we understand that we need to choose the first meaning of the adjective ‘smart’ for the test sentence: ‘Peter always dresses how? – in a stylish way’, therefore, we are to change the adjective ‘smart’ into the adverb of manner that is usually placed either after the main verb or after the object. Adverbs of manner are often formed from adjectives by adding -ly: bad – badly, brave bravely, sudden – suddenly. Thus, we need to add –ly to the adjective ‘smart’: ‘smart’ → ‘smartly’.The variants ‘smartful’ and ‘smarty’ are nonce-words.

Task: The actor, ______ David likes, is Bradley Cooper.
comment: What' is a question word, it cannot be used here. We use 'which' for animals and objects. 'Whose' refers to possession and 'whom' is used as an object.

Task: We all have no hope ____ successful performance of our team.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'no hope of'

Task: "The book ""The adventures of Tom Sawyer"" was written _____ Mark Twain."
comment: It is correct to say 'written by somebody'

Task: It was very stupid _____ him to go there alone.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'stupid of'

Task: There are a lot of _______ (a person) in the club.
comment: The right plural form of the noun 'person' is 'people'.

Task: Would you like ________ tea?
comment: We use 'some' in positive sentences and 'any' in negative ones before countable or uncountable nouns. 'Many' and 'a few' are used before plural countable nouns
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: If Chris _________ (to be) late I ________ (to leave) without him.
comment: When we speak about probable situations in the present or future we use Conditional 1: If-clause (if + Present Simple) - Main Clause (future/modal + present without 'to') or If-clause (if + Present Simple) - Main Clause (future + HAVE TO, OUGHT TO, BE TO + present without 'to').

Task: "The coach: ""Don't be too late""."
a: The coach asked me had not to be too late.
b: The coach asked me did not to be too late.
c: The coach asked me not to be too late.
d: The coach asked me would not to be too late.
comment: When we need to transform a request into Reported Speech we use an introductory verb + the to-infinitive: asked not + to be

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: Five years before in London had Katie met Jim.
b: Katie had five years before met Jim in London.
c: Katie five years before had met Jim in London.
d: Katie had met Jim in London five years before.
comment: There is a certain word order in statements with the Past Perfect Tense: Subject - Auxiliary - Predicate - Object. When we need to mention information about time and place, it is better to say at first 'where' and then 'when'.

Task: _ Africa is the world's second largest continent.
comment: The' is not used before names of continents.

Task: Michael _________ (to have) this car for five years.
comment: The action in this sentence started in the Past and continues in the Present. It means that Michael still has this car. In this case we should use the Present Perfect Tense:  has/have + Verb (-ed/Irregular)

Task: I was listening to music when my mom __________ (to enter) my room.
comment: In this case the first action was in progress when suddenly something interrupted it. For a longer action we use the Past Continuous Tense. The second action was shorter so we should use the Past Simple Tense.

Task: The company __________ (to open) a new cinema tomorrow.
comment: We use the Future Simple Tense when we talk about common actions and facts which will happen in the future.

Task: The Tudor dynasty _______________ (to establish) in 1485.
comment: When we don't know who carries out the action, or it is obvious or unimportant to us, we use the Passive voice. The Passive is formed: BE + Past Participle. In this sentence the action took place at a certain time in the past, so we use the Past Simple Passive.

Task: Pupils  __________ wear a school uniform in some countries.
comment: We use the modal verb 'have to' when it is not our idea to do something, when we are forced to do something by somebody or by circumstances.

Task: I don't want _________ (to quarrel) with you but you are so wrong.
comment: Phrasal verbs are verbs that consist of a verb and a particle and/or a preposition. Phrasal verbs are typical of spoken English or informal writing, e.g. letters to friends and articles in popular journalism. They cannot be understood based upon the meanings of the individual parts in isolation, thus, their meanings are unpredictable. The phrasal verb 'to fall out with' means 'to quarrel'.

Task: Choose  two forms of the verb 'to blow' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO BLOW - BLEW - BLOWN

Task: It seems Mark and Jane have taken my umbrella because I can see only _______ on the shelf.
comment: There are two types of possessive pronouns: (1) possessive pronouns (mine, hers, ours, etc.) and (2) possessive determiners (my, your, his, her, its, our and their). We use them to refer to possession and ‘belonging’. We use possessive determiners before nouns: Is that your dress? But we use possessive pronouns without a noun: This handbag is very similar to mine.In the test sentence ‘It seems Mark and Jane have taken my umbrella because I can see only _______ on the shelf.’ there is not any noun after the omitted word: ‘I can see only what?’. Therefore, some possessive pronoun is omitted. As the context is given in the test: ‘…Mark and Jane have taken my umbrella …’, it is supposed that Mark and Jane (they) left their umbrella. Therefore, the possessive pronoun that correlates with the personal subject pronoun ‘they’ is ‘theirs’: ‘they’ (the personal subject pronoun) → ‘theirs’ (the possessive pronoun).Therefore, we choose ANSWER 4: theirs.

Task: My grandmother knitted a ______ _______ _______ (new/black/winter) sweater.
comment: There is a certain word order in sentences with two or more adjectives: OPINION-SIZE-AGE-SHAPE-COLOUR-ORIGIN-MATERIAL-TYPE. Here: a new (age) black (colour) winter (type)sweater.

Task: Mick wrote the letter _________.
comment: We use adverbs to describe time, degree, manner, etc. In other words adverbs help us get more information about the action or the place (where, when, how, how often, etc.) Many adverbs are formed from adding '-ly' or '-ily' to the adjective.

Task: The car ______ belongs to Mary is red.
comment: We use 'which' or 'that' for things in relative clauses.  'Whose' and 'whom' are used as objects.

Task: Smoking has a negative effect ___ our health.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'effect on'

Task: You should go about 300 metres _____ the mall and turn to the left.
comment: In this sentence we need to choose a preposition that collocates with the verb go: ‘go about 300 metres where? → the mall’.The preposition ‘towards’ means ‘in the direction of, or closer to someone or something’: She stood up and walked (where?) towards him. We could also use here the preposition ‘to’.

Task: My car is covered ______ snow.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'covered with'

Task: There are four _______ (a knife) on the table.
comment: Some nouns have spelling changes. A KNIFE - TWO KNIVES

Task: I think ________ is wrong with my smartphone. I can't send a message.
comment: We use the pronoun 'something' to refer to things in affirmative sentences, while 'anything' in negative ones. 'Any' and 'some' are pronouns that doesn't relate to the meaning of the sentence.
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: If Mike __________ (to be) brave he __________ (to go) on safari.
comment: When we speak about imaginary situations which differ from real facts in the present we use Conditional 2: If-clause (if + Past Simple) - Main Clause (would/could + present without 'to'). The meaning of this sentence: in reality Mike is not brave and he has never gone on safari.

Task: "Katty: ""I'll be there at 7 p.m."""
a: Katty said that she had been there at 7 p.m.
b: Katty said that she has been there at 7 p.m.
c: Katty said that she was there at 7 p.m.
d: Katty said that she would be there at 7 p.m.
comment: We change the Future Simple to the Conditional in Reported Speech: will - would.

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: A famous American actress Marilyn Monroe was.
b: Marilyn Monroe was a famous American actress.
c: Marilyn Monroe a famous American actress was.
d: Was Marilyn Monroe a famous American actress.
comment: There is a certain word order in statements: Subject - Auxiliary - Object. 'Marilyn Monroe' is a subject, 'was' - an auxiliary verb, 'a famous American actress' - an object.

Task: Chris works in _ Hague.
comment: The' is not used before names of cities and suburbs, but there are some exceptions: the Hague, the Bronx.

Task: Actually, I __________ (not / to like) apples.
comment: When we talk about things in general, permanent situations and states or things that happen sometimes, we always use the Present Simple Tense: [I/you/we/they/ + Verb] and [he/she/it + Verb+ -s(es)]

Task: I was trying to concentrate when suddenly Sarah ____________ (to give) me a fright.
comment: In this case the first action was in progress when suddenly something interrupted it. For a longer action we use the Past Continuous Tense. The second action was shorter so we should use the Past Simple Tense. The verb 'to give' is irregular: GIVE - GAVE - GIVEN

Task: It's so difficult to make a choice. Ok, I _________ (to buy) the red one.
comment: We use the Future Simple Tense when we have no plan or decision before we speak. We make it at the time of speaking.

Task: The theatre _______________ (to build) next year.
comment: When we don't know who carries out the action, or it is obvious or unimportant to us, we use the Passive voice. In this sentence we speak about the action which will be completed in the future: Will Be + Past Participle.

Task: I'm very busy today. I ____________________ stay at work till night.
comment: We use the modal verb 'have to' when it is not our idea to do something, when we are forced to do something by somebody or by circumstances.

Task: I __________ (to be friendly to each other) with my younger sister very well. We are like close friends.
comment: Phrasal verbs are verbs that consist of a verb and a particle and/or a preposition. Phrasal verbs are typical of spoken English or informal writing, e.g. letters to friends and articles in popular journalism. They cannot be understood based upon the meanings of the individual parts in isolation, thus, their meanings are unpredictable. The phrasal verb 'to get along with' means 'to be friendly to each other'.

Task: Choose  two forms of the verb 'to fall' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO FALL - FELL - FALLEN

Task: Hey, Carl! Do you see _____ ? I'm standing in front of the monument.
comment: Here the pronoun should be used in its objective form. 'Me' is the right form of the personal pronoun 'I'.

Task: I wouldn't trust Jeremy. I think he's ________ .
comment: The un- (= ‘not’) prefix is commonly attached to Latin derivatives that end in suffixes such as -ed and -able, resulting in adjectives such as unfounded, unassailable, and unbelievable.The adjective ‘reliable’ that means ‘able to be trusted to do or provide what is needed ’ (a reliable friend) has the suffix ‘able’. The morpheme ‘rely’ is of Latin origin and comes from the Latin word ‘religāre’ that meant ‘to bind fast, hold firmly’. Thus, we need to add the prefix ‘un-’ to the adjective ‘reliable’. The adjective ‘unreliable’ means ‘not able to be trusted or believed’ (Angie is completely unreliable.) and it is the opposite of the adjective ‘reliable’.

Task: Richard works ________.
comment: We use adverbs to describe time, degree, manner, etc. In other words adverbs help us get more information about the action or the place (where, when, how, how often, etc.) Many adverbs are formed from adding '-ly' or '-ily' to the adjective.

Task: Peter played with a boy ______ studied with him.
comment: We use 'that' and 'who' for people in relative clauses.  'Whose' and 'whom' are used as objects.

Task: This website provides many recipes _____ dinner that you can prepare in 30 minutes.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'recipe for'

Task: I'm stuck in a traffic jam. I need to get ______ the bus or otherwise I'll be late.
comment: In this sentence we are given the context ‘get ______ the bus’. The phrasal verb ‘get off sth’ means ‘to leave a train,bus, or aircraft’: Make sure you take your belongings when you get off the plane.Thus, we are to choose ANSWER 3 (off) in the test.

Task: I'm very nervous _______ the competition.
comment: We can use three prepositions after the adjective ‘nervous’: (1) ‘about’ (Her father was nervous about her walking home so late.); (2) ‘of’ (My wife has always been a little nervous of change.) and (3) ‘for’ - the same as nervous about (I’m so nervous for Monday’s exam!).

Task: We saw nine _________ (a wolf) in the zoo.
comment: Some nouns have spelling changes in plural. A WOLF - TWO WOLVES

Task: We have ________ black pepper left for cooking supper.
comment: A little' is used before uncountable nouns. 'Many', 'a few' and 'few' - before countable
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: If you ________ (to be) attentive you _______ (to pass) the exam.
comment: When we speak about probable situations in the present or future we use Conditional 1: If-clause (if + Present Simple) - Main Clause (future/modal + present without 'to') or If-clause (if + Present Simple) - Main Clause (future + HAVE TO, OUGHT TO, BE TO + present without 'to').

Task: "Teresa: ""He has done everything wrong again""."
a: Teresa said that he did everything wrong again.
b: Teresa said that he had been doing everything wrong again.
c: Teresa said that he has done everything wrong again.
d: Teresa said that he had done everything wrong again.
comment: We change the Present Perfect to the Past Perfect in Reported Speech.

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: 2,500 kilometers long The Great Wall of China is.
b: The Great Wall of China is 2,500 kilometers long.
c: Is The Great Wall of China 2,500 kilometers long.
d: The Great Wall of China 2,500 kilometers is long.
comment: There is a certain word order in statements: Subject - Auxiliary - Object. 'The Great Wall of China' is a subject, 'is' - an auxiliary verb, '2,500 kilometers long' - an object.

Task: We are going to travel around _ Europe next year.
comment: The' is not used before names of continents.

Task: I can bring Tom's umbrella back now. He ___________ (to return) from France recently.
comment: The action in this sentence has been completed recently and we see the result of it in the present. In this case we should use the present Perfect Tense:  has/have + Verb (-ed/Irregular)

Task: Bob was reading a book while the children ____________ (to sleep).
comment: We use the Past Continuous Tense when we talk about two or more simultaneous actions in the past. We use the auxiliary verb 'were' for plural forms of nouns.

Task: I wanted to go for a walk but I'm too tired to do something today. I ____________ (to stay) at home and watch TV.
comment: If we have a plan, ambition or intention to do something in the future we use 'be going to’. If we choose ANSWER 1 (am going to stay), we create the context that the speaker has future intentions that have been decided but have not been fully planned (referring to the past decision) that is expressed by the construction ‘be going to’.

Task: "The film ""Casino"" __________ (to direct) by Martin Scorsese in 1995."
comment: Sometimes we need to change a sentence from the Active Voice into the Passive Voice. We can also know a person who carries out the action. In this case we use the Passive Voice and form a sentence according to this rule:  Subject - Be+ Past Participle - Preposition 'BY' - Agent (who or what carries out the action). Here we use the Past Simple Passive because we have a certain time in the past: 1995.

Task: I'm sorry, I _____________ hear you.
comment: The modal verb 'can' is used when we speak about the ability in the Present.

Task: We are planning to _________ (to start a journey) at 10 o'clock tomorrow.
comment: Phrasal verbs are verbs that consist of a verb and a particle and/or a preposition. Phrasal verbs are typical of spoken English or informal writing, e.g. letters to friends and articles in popular journalism. They cannot be understood based upon the meanings of the individual parts in isolation, thus, their meanings are unpredictable. The phrasal verb 'to set off' means 'to start a journey'.

Task: Choose two forms of the verb 'to shake' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO SHAKE - SHOOK - SHAKEN

Task: Darrel, could you hold on, please? I want to tell you _______ .
comment: Somebody' and 'nothing' do not relate to the meaning of the sentence. 'Anything' is used in negative sentences, while 'something' is used in affirmative ones.

Task: David's story is ________ than Kelly's one.
comment: When we compare two things or two people we use the comparative form of adjectives. If we use an adjective with three or more syllables we add 'more' before it.

Task: Finally, they returned home ________.
comment: We use adverbs to describe time, degree, manner, etc. In other words adverbs help us get more information about the action or the place (where, when, how, how often, etc.) Many adverbs are formed from adding '-ly' or '-ily' to the adjective.

Task: Tom gave me the present, ______ was wrapped beautifully.
comment: We use 'which' or 'that' for things in relative clauses.  'Whose' and 'whom' are used as objects.

Task: There are many advantages ____ living in a city.
comment: For this sentence we need to choose the preposition after the noun ‘advantage’ that means ‘something that makes one person or thing more likely to succeed than others’.We can use two prepositions after the noun ‘advantage’: (1) ‘of’ (One of the many advantages of living in New York is that you can eat out at almost any time of day.); (2) ‘over’ (The home team always have an advantage over their opponents.). Therefore, among the test answers we are to choose ANSWER4 (of).

Task: Tom's birthday is ____ July.
comment: It is correct to say 'in July'

Task: He is addicted ______ music.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'addicted to'

Task: How many _______ of birds are there in the world?
comment: There are some nouns which have the same form in the singular and in the plural: ONE SPECIES - TWO SPECIES

Task: I want to make a cake but I don't have ________ flour.
comment: Much' is used before uncountable nouns. 'Many', 'a few' - before countable. We use 'some' in positive sentences.
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: If I ___________ (to be) you I __________ (not to go) to the rock concert alone.
comment: When we speak about imaginary situations which differ from real facts in the present we use Conditional 2: If-clause (if + Past Simple) - Main Clause (would/could + present without 'to'). The meaning of this sentence: in reality my friend is going to rock concert alone and I recommend her not to do it.

Task: "Jill: ""I'm writing a letter now""."
a: Jill said that she had been writing a letter then.
b: Jill said that she was writing a letter now.
c: Jill said that she was writing a letter then.
d: Jill said that she had been writing a letter now.
comment: We change the Present Continuous to the Past Continuous in Reported Speech. Also we change some time expressions: now - then

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart was in 1756 in Salzburg born.
b: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart was born in Salzburg in 1756.
c: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart was born in 1756 in Salzburg.
d: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart in 1756 in Salzburg was born.
comment: There is a certain word order in statements: Subject - Auxiliary - Predicate - Object. When we need to mention information about time and place, it is better to say at first 'where' and then 'when'.

Task: Tom sent me a photo of _ Trafalgar Square. It's amazing!
comment: The is not used before names of squares.

Task: Oh my God! He __________ (just/to win) the race!
comment: The action in this sentence has been completed recently and we see the result of it in the present. In this case we should use the present Perfect Tense:  has/have + Verb (-ed/Past Participle)

Task: The first Derby __________ (to take) place in May 1780.
comment: We use the Past Simple Tense when we talk about actions which happened at a certain time in the past.

Task: I don't know what to do. I can't visit you, because I _________ (to leave) for London tomorrow.
comment: If we have decided to do something or arranged to do something in the near future we use 'be going to'.

Task: This sweater ____________ (to make) of wool.
comment: When we don't know who carries out the action, or it is obvious or unimportant to us, we use the Passive voice. The Passive is formed: BE + Past Participle

Task: _______ you take an umbrella, please?
comment: We use the modal verb 'could' when we ask somebody to do something.

Task: Ben doesn't know what to do in this situation. I think he'll ___________ (to surrender) some day.
comment: Phrasal verbs are verbs that consist of a verb and a particle and/or a preposition. Phrasal verbs are typical of spoken English or informal writing, e.g. letters to friends and articles in popular journalism. They cannot be understood based upon the meanings of the individual parts in isolation, thus, their meanings are unpredictable. The phrasal verb 'to give in' means 'to surrender'.

Task: Choose two forms of the verb 'to hide' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO HIDE - HID - HIDDEN

Task: Jessy, do you know _______ who can help me?
comment: Everybody' and 'nobody' do not relate to the meaning of the sentence. 'Anybody' is used in interrogative sentences, while 'somebody' is used in affirmative ones.

Task: Teachers think that Rachel is _______ girl in the group.
comment: When we compare a person or a thing with more than one person or one thing we use the superlative form of adjectives. If we use a one-syllable adjective we add '-est' to it.

Task: They live together ________.
comment: We use adverbs to describe time, degree, manner, etc. In other words adverbs help us get more information about the action or the place (where, when, how, how often, etc.) Many adverbs are formed from adding '-ly' or '-ily' to the adjective.

Task: Paul finally met a lady, ______ helped him find the way to the cinema.
comment: We use 'who' for people in relative clauses when 'who' is a subject. 'Whose' and 'whom' are used as objects. We use 'which' to refer to animals and objects.

Task: He gave a poor excuse _____ his behavior.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'excuse for'

Task: I like to travel ____ summer.
comment: It is correct to say 'in summer'

Task: John is crazy ______ Mary.
comment: There is an idiom ‘be crazy about sb/sth’ that means ‘to be very interested in something or love someone very much’: My sons are crazy about football. Therefore, among the test variants we are to choose ANSWER 3 (about).

Task: This airport can handle more than 300 _______ (an aircraft) every day.
comment: There are some nouns which have the same form in the singular and in the plural: ONE AIRCRAFT - TWO AIRCRAFT

Task: I see ________ people outside.
comment: Many' is used before countable nouns. 'Much' and 'a little' - before uncountable. We use 'any' in negative sentences.
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: I ________ (to try) to help you if you ________ (to tell) me what's wrong.
comment: When we speak about probable situations in the present or future we use Conditional 1: If-clause (if + Present Simple) - Main Clause (future/modal + present without 'to') or If-clause (if + Present Simple) - Main Clause (future + HAVE TO, OUGHT TO, BE TO + present without 'to').

Task: "Melanie: ""Where have you bought these shoes?"""
a: Melanie asked me where I bought those shoes.
b: Melanie asked me where did I buy those shoes.
c: Melanie asked me where had I had bought those shoes.
d: Melanie asked me where I had bought those shoes.
comment: Melanie asked me where I had bought those shoes.' - this is the right word order in Reported Speech for special questions. We add 'where' before a pronoun and then place the auxiliary verb.  Here we change the Present Perfect into the Past Perfect.

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: Kyle will tell you this story in the park tomorrow.
b: Kyle will tell you tomorrow this story in the park.
c: Kyle  tomorrow will tell you this story in the park.
d: Kyle  will tell you this story tomorrow in the park.
comment: There is a certain word order in statements: Subject - Verb - Object. In standard English we normally use the object of place before the object of time: in the park tomorrow.

Task: Do you know when __ Antarctica was officially discovered?
comment: The is not used before names of continents.

Task: I _____ (to live) here since childhood and I think I know everyone in our village.
comment: Since shows us that the action started in the past and continues up to now. That is why we use Present Perfect: has/have + Verb (-ed/Past Participle)

Task: Jake _______ (to roast) meat in the oven while Cara ________ (to knead) dough.
comment: While indicates simultaneous actions. In this case we use the Past Continuous Tense for both actions.

Task: I ______ (to send) you photos when I get them.
comment: If a speaker suggests to do something voluntarily - we use the Future Simple.

Task: Transfer this Active Voice sentence into the Passive one: Britain kept Napoleon on the island of Saint Helena.
a: Napoleon was been kept on the island of Saint Helena  by England.
b: Napoleon had kept on the island of Saint Helena  by England.
c: Napoleon kept on the island of Saint Helena  by England.
d: Napoleon was kept on the island of Saint Helena by England.
comment: The Passive Voice is formed according to this rule:  Subject - Be+ Past Participle - Preposition 'BY' - Agent (who or what carries out the action). The right form for the Past Simple Passive is: was/were + past participle or verb+ -ed

Task: ____ a doctor, I want to define the illnesses. Unfortunately I'm an IT specialist and don't have medicine knowledge.
comment: Like means 'similar to'. It means that the speaker is not a doctor. 'As a doctor' means 'being a doctor'.

Task: Darling, could you ______ (to reverse, to move backward) the car? There's a large puddle near my door, I can't get out.
comment: Phrasal verb 'to back up' means 'to reverse, to move backward'.

Task: Choose two forms of the verb 'to cast' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO CAST-CAST-CAST

Task: We could phone Jill later, ___________ we have to hurry up.
comment: The meaning of this sentence is: we are in a hurry so we have no time to phone Jill. 'We have no time' is the reason why we cannot phone Jill. To give a reason for a certain situation we use 'seeing that, seeing as, as, because, since' + clause. Other given linking words do not relate to the meaning of the sentence.

Task: Little Johnny is a (an) _______ brilliant boy!
comment: Some words can make adjectives stronger. We call these words 'intensifiers'. Some of them are: very, really, pretty, absolutely. Remember that with strong adjectives (with extreme meaning) like 'brilliant' we use certain intensifiers. For example: exceptionally, completely, absolutely, totally, utterly, quite.

Task: She looked at him ________ .
comment: We use adverbs to describe time, degree, manner, etc. In other words adverbs help us get more information about the action or a place (where, when, how, how often, etc.)They are formed by adding '-ly' or '-ily' to the adjective.

Task: My grandmother enjoys ________ (to swim) in the sea.
comment: Enjoy requires the Gerund. In this case the Gerund is used as the object of the verb.

Task: People joined a walk through the town __ memory __ the poet.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions before and after them: 'in memory of'.

Task: The meeting is scheduled __ Friday evening.
comment: It is correct to say 'on Friday evening'.

Task: Martin is looking for a job and a place to move in. He doesn't want to be overly dependent __ his parents.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'dependent on'.

Task: Unfortunately, hunters kill many ________  every year.
comment: There are some nouns which have the same form in the singular and in the plural: ONE GROUSE - TWO GROUSE.

Task: It was the worst birthday ever. ____ friends visited me.
comment: Few is used with countable nouns and means 'Almost no friends visited me'. 'A few' is also used with countable nouns, but means 'Enough friends visited me'. It is a positive meaning and does not relate to the context. 'A little' and 'much' are used with uncountable nouns.
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: Express disappointment with the present situation: I have to do this task. I don't want to do it.
a: If only I had done that task.
b: I wish I didn’t have to do that task.
c: I would do that task if I had to.
d: I didn't want to do that task but I had to.
comment: To express disappointment with the present situation we usually use the construction [ I + wish + Past Simple]. Other answers do not relate to the meaning.

Task: Use a prefix to make a word negative: fair
comment: We say 'fair - unfair'

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: My grandfather a passionate numismatist was.
c: A passionate numismatist my grandfather was.
d: My grandfather was a passionate numismatist.
comment: There is a certain word order in statements: Subject - Verb - Object. 'My grandfather' is a subject, 'was' - an auxiliary verb, 'a passionate numismatist' - an object

Task: ___ Bronx is the third most densely populated county in the U.S.
comment: The is not used before names of cities and suburbs, but there are some exceptions: the Hague, the Bronx, the Plains (Virginia).

Task: Hey, Patrick! Don't forget, that the party ______ (to start) at 9 o'clock!
comment: We use Present Simple to talk about scheduled events which will happen in the near future.

Task: Kate was sleeping when her alarm clock ______( to go off).
comment: In this case the first action was in progress when suddenly something interrupted it. For a longer action we use the Past Continuous Tense. The second action was shorter so we use the Past Simple Tense.

Task: I _______ (to read) a newspaper when mom arrives tonight.
comment: We use the Future Continuous Tense to show that some activity will be in progress at a certain point of time in the future

Task: Transfer this Active Voice sentence into the Passive one: It is known that pirates kidnapped Julius Caesar on the way across the Aegean Sea.
a: It is known that Julius Caesar had kidnapped by pirates on the way across the Aegean Sea.
b: It is known that Julius Caesar was kidnapped by pirates on the way across the Aegean Sea.
c: It is known that Julius Caesar was kidnapping by pirates on the way across the Aegean Sea.
d: It is known that Julius Caesar kidnapped pirates on the way across the Aegean Sea.
comment: The Passive Voice is formed according to this rule:  Subject - Be+ Past Participle - Preposition 'BY' - Agent (who or what carries out the action). The right form for Past Simple Passive is: was/were + past participle or verb+ -ed. Other answers are incorrect or illogical.

Task: Paula wants to lose 10 kilos. But she  _____ no attempt to reach this aim.
comment: We say 'to make an attempt'.

Task: The bus ______ (to stop working, functioning) so I had to go on foot.
comment: Phrasal verb 'to break down' means 'to stop working, functioning'.

Task: Choose  two forms of the verb 'to overthrow' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO OVERTHROW-OVERTHREW-OVERTHROWN

Task: _______  the accident the flight was delayed.
comment: The accident' is the reason why the flight was delayed. To introduce a reason we could use 'owing to' and 'since'. But you should remember that after 'since' we place a clause. Linking words of reason that are followed by a noun are: owing to, due to, because of.  Other given linking words do not relate to the meaning of the sentence.

Task: Mark is a pretty ________ child.
comment: Six-year-old is the only correct answer. Remember that such adjectives are constructed in this word order: number-year-old.

Task: The politician _____ overcame uneasy and awkward questions from journalists.
comment: We use adverbs to describe time, degree, manner, etc. In other words adverbs help us get more information about the action or a place (where, when, how, how often, etc.). They are formed by adding '-ly' or '-ily' to the adjective.

Task: My little brother wants _______ (to play) football again.
comment: Want requires the Infinitive. We cannot use the Gerund with this verb.

Task: My little sister likes fairy tales ____ Hans Christian Andersen.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'fairy tales (poems and etc) by...'.

Task: It's always uneasy to find an interesting book ____ hundreds of others  in the bookstore.
comment: It is correct to say 'to find among others' when we mean 'to discover the necessary thing in the midst of others'.

Task: Jane is not very keen ___ sport.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'keen on'

Task: Tom Harris, a 36-year-old firefighter, saved 3 _____ after a fire broke out in a house.
comment: Some nouns have spelling changes in plural. A LIFE - NINE LIVES.

Task: I need ______ money. Jeremy, could you lend me 3 dollars?
comment: A few is used with countable nouns and means 'some'. 'A little' is used with uncountable nouns and also means 'some'. 'Any' is used in negative sentences. 'Many' is used with countable nouns.
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: Express regret about the past: It's a pity that I didn't know her before.
a: I would have known her before.
b: I would like to know her before.
c: I wish I have known her before.
d: I wish I had known her before.
comment: When we want to show regret about the past we usually use the construction [ I + wish + Past Perfect]. Other answers do not relate to the meaning.

Task: Use a prefix to make a word negative: competent
comment: We say 'competent - incompetent'

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: Robert gave to the child a cookie.
b: Robert gave a cookie to the child.
c: A cookie Robert gave to the child.
d: A cookie gave Robert the child.
comment: When we say 'give Something to somebody' we place the indirect object after the direct object: Robert gave a cookie to the child. But when we omit 'to' the indirect object should be placed in front of the direct object. Answers 3 and 4 do not follow the word order: Subject - Verb - Object

Task: The last eruption of __ Kilimanjaro volcano happened about 200 years ago.
comment: When the word 'volcano' is used, the definite article 'THE' should be placed before the name of the volcano.

Task: Where's Monica? I haven't seen her since Monday. - She's at home. She ______ (recently / to break) her arm.
comment: If we see in the present the result  of the event which happened in the past - we use the Present Perfect. Here: Monica's broken arm is the result of some accident of the past. The Present Perfect Tense is formed:  has/have + Verb (-ed/Past Participle)

Task: The children were making origami when their babysitter ______ (to call) them to dinner.
comment: In this case the first action was in progress when suddenly the second one interrupted it. For a longer action we use the Past Continuous Tense. The second action was shorter so we use the Past Simple Tense.

Task: If I'm elected the Head of the company, I _____ (to raise) wages.
comment: When we talk about promises we usually use the Future Simple Tense

Task: Transfer this Active Voice sentence into the Passive one: The Congress signed the Declaration  on July 4 in 1776.
a: The Declaration had signed by the Congress on July 4 in 1776.
b: The Congress was signed by the Declaration on July 4 in 1776.
c: The Declaration has been signed by the Congress on July 4 in 1776.
d: The Declaration was signed by the Congress on July 4 in 1776.
comment: In this sentence the action took place at a certain time in the past, so we use the Past Simple Passive: was/were + Past Participle. Answer 2 is illogical because the Declaration cannot be the doer of an action.

Task: It is important to me to _____ business with honest partners.
comment: We say 'to do business'.

Task: Melanie _______ (to devote the day) to her kids and parents.
comment: Phrasal verb 'to give over' means 'to dedicate all the time to somebody or to something'.

Task: Choose  two forms of the verb 'to backslide' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO BACKSLIDE-BACKSLID-BACKSLID

Task: Jeremy works hard ________ to prove he deserves to get a higher position.
comment: To prove he deserves to get a higher position is a purpose why Jeremy works hard. When we introduce a purpose we use 'in order/so as + to-infinitive' or 'so (that)/in order (that) + clause'. Other given linking words do not relate to the meaning of the sentence.

Task: I bought ______ (riding/beautiful/black) boots yesterday.
comment: There is a certain word order in sentences with two or more adjectives: OPINION-SIZE-AGE-SHAPE-COLOUR-ORIGIN-MATERIAL-PURPOSE. Here: beautiful (opinion) black (colour) riding (purpose)

Task: Our friends ________ invited us to visit their new home in Stradford.
comment: We use adverbs to describe time, degree, manner, etc. In other words adverbs help us get more information about the action or a place (where, when, how, how often, etc.) They are formed by adding '-ly' or '-ily' to the adjective.

Task: Stacey stopped ________ (to drink) some water. She made a pause during her jogging.
comment: Some verbs can be used both with the Gerund and the Infinitive. But in some cases the meaning of the sentence becomes different. Compare: stopped to drink - stopped one activity in order to start another one / stopped drinking - she is not drinking anymore.

Task: The government will certainly give an appropriate reply ___ the challenge thrown by radical parties.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'a reply to'.

Task: What's the distinction ______ hardware and software?
comment: It is correct to say 'distinction between'.

Task: Our transport system is very similar ___ Berlin's one.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'similar to'.

Task: A stranger gave a beggar two _______ (a loaf) of bread and a bottle of water.
comment: Some nouns have spelling changes: A LOAF - LOAVES

Task: Dear, have you bought ___ apples?
comment: We usually use 'any' in questions.
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: Express the idea when you want someone to do something in the present or future: It's late. Don't go there alone.
a: If only you hadn't gone there alone.
b: I wish you hadn't gone there alone.
c: I'd rather you went there alone.
d: I'd rather you didn't go there alone.
comment: When we need to express the idea when you want someone to do something in the present or future we usually use the construction [would rather + subject + Past Simple]. Other answers do not relate to the meaning.

Task: Use a suffix to form an adjective from a given word: guilt
comment: We say 'guilt - guilty'

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: Why can't we have a cup of coffee at first?
b: Why we can't have a cup of coffee at first?
c: Can't why we have a cup of coffee at first?
d: Why have  we can't  a cup of coffee at first?
comment: The right word order in the wh-question is: Question Word - Auxiliary or Modal - Subject - Main Verb - Object. 'Why' is a question word, 'can' - a modal verb, 'we' - a subject, 'have' - main verb, 'a cup of coffee at first' - an object.

Task: It has been announced that ___ Pope is going to visit Warsaw.
comment: We know that there is the only Pope in the world, so we use definite article 'the'.

Task: Samuel _______ (not to leave) the office yet. He wants to finish his report by tomorrow morning.
comment: The action in this sentence started at an unstated time in the Past and continues in the Present. It means that  Samuel is still in the office. In this case we should use the Present Perfect Tense:  has/have + Verb (-ed/Past Participle).

Task: Benjamin _______ (to watch) a movie before Alison _______ (to come) in.
comment: Past Perfect Continuous emphasizes the duration of an action in the past before another one. We cannot use Past Continuous because this Tense wouldn't show that the first action started before the second one.

Task: Luke ____ (to let) us know when he finds the keys to the apartment.
comment: We use the Future Simple Tense when we talk about common actions and facts which will happen in the future.

Task: Transfer this Active Voice sentence into the Passive one: French sculptor Frederic Auguste Bartholdi designed the statue of Liberty.
a: The statue of Liberty has been designed by French sculptor Frederic Auguste Bartholdi.
b: The statue of Liberty designed by French sculptor Frederic Auguste Bartholdi.
c: French sculptor Frederic Auguste Bartholdi was designed by the statue of Liberty.
d: The statue of Liberty was designed by French sculptor Frederic Auguste Bartholdi.
comment: In this sentence the action took place at in the past, so we use the Past Simple Passive: was/were + Past Participle. Answer 3 is illogical because the statue of Liberty cannot be the doer of an action.

Task: My neighbors _______ a terrible noise every evening.
comment: We say 'to make a noise'.

Task: Oh, don't pay attention to me, _______  (to continue) your conversation, please.
comment: Phrasal verb 'to carry on' means 'to go on or continue with something'.

Task: Choose  two forms of the verb 'to tear' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO TEAR - TORE - TORN

Task: John had been playing football all morning. ________ he's exhausted.
comment: When we talk about a result we use 'so, therefore, as a result, for this reason'. Notice that they are usually come at the beginning of the sentence but it is possible for 'so' and 'therefore' to take also a middle position. Other given linking words do not relate to the meaning of the sentence.

Task: Audi or BMW: which do you like _____ ?
comment: It is correct to say 'which do you like better'

Task: Our team played ______ last month.
comment: We use adverbs to describe time, degree, manner, etc. In other words adverbs help us get more information about the action or a place (where, when, how, how often, etc.)They are formed by adding '-ly' or '-ily' to the adjective.

Task: Jeremy stopped _______ (to smoke) a year ago. He doesn't want to start smoking anymore.
comment: Some verbs can be used both with the Gerund and the Infinitive. But in some cases the meaning of the sentence becomes different. Compare: stopped to smoke - stopped one activity in order to start another one / stopped smoking - he doesn't smoke anymore.

Task: His fear __ flying is always a problem.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'fear of'

Task: She always stands out for what she believes __ .
comment: It is correct to say 'believe in'.

Task: Her husband was accused __ cheating with a 26-year-old model.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'accused of'.

Task: I think we should move our ______ (a ski) to garage.
comment: The right plural form of the noun 'ski' is 'skis'

Task: It's too dark in the room, I can hardly see ________ here.
comment: We use 'any / anything' in negative sentences and in positive sentences with 'never, hardly, without'.
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: If Charlie _____ (to leave) the house earlier, he ______ (to be) late for work.
comment: When we speak about past unreal condition we use: If-clause (if + Past Perfect) - Main Clause (would have + past participle).

Task: Use a suffix to form a noun from a given word: recover
comment: We say 'recovery'

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: Trouble may I you for a napkin?
b: I may you trouble for a napkin?
c: May trouble I you for a napkin?
d: May I trouble you for a napkin?
comment: When we want to ask a question with a modal verb we must place it in the first place: Modal Verb - Subject - Verb - Object. 'May' is a modal verb, 'I' - a subject, 'trouble' - verb, 'you for the napkin' - an object.

Task: They have been married for __ sixteen years.
comment: When we use numerals before nouns we don't use articles.

Task: It's just tactlessly of her. I _______ (to wait) for her all day and she's still not here.
comment: When we talk about unspecified period of time and an action which started before now and continues in the present - we use the Present Perfect Continuous. Also this tense shows that the speaker wants to highlight a process rather than a result.

Task: My brother _______ (to look for) a job for 2 months before they _______ (to employ) him.
comment: The action in the first part (had been looking for) took place before the action in the second one (employed). Another important moment is that the speaker focuses on the process rather than the action (for 2 months). That is why we use the Past Perfect Continuous in the first part.

Task: By the time you write the report I ______ (to leave).
comment: We use the Future Perfect to show that one action will be completed before another one in the future. Here: I will leave before you finish the report.

Task: Transfer this Active Voice sentence into the Passive one: The discovery of Pluto took place in 1930.
d: The discovery of Pluto was taken place in 1930.
comment: The Passive Voice is formed according to this rule:  Subject - Be+ Past Participle - Preposition 'BY' - Agent (who or what carries out the action). The right form for the Past Simple Passive is: was/were + past participle or verb+ -ed

Task: Garry is going to _______ an exam next week.
comment: We say 'to take an exam'.

Task: We had a quarrel last night but we could ________ (to forgive each other) in the morning.
comment: Phrasal verb 'to make up' means 'to forgive each other'.

Task: Choose  two forms of the verb 'to seek' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO SEEK - SOUGHT - SOUGHT

Task: ________ rescue teams had been searching the lost climbers all night, they couldn't find any trace of them.
comment: When we want to show that there is a surprising contrast between two statements in one sentence we use 'although, though, even though' and 'despite/in spite of + -ing/noun/pronoun'. Other given linking words do not relate to the meaning of the sentence.

Task: Our breakfast turned out to be ________. So we wrote a complaint letter to the kitchen manager.
comment: Inedible describes food that is not suitable for eating

Task: - What time are we meeting? - At seven o'clock _____.
comment: We use adverbs to describe time, degree, manner, etc. In other words adverbs help us get more information about the action or a place (where, when, how, how often, etc.)They are formed by adding '-ly' or '-ily' to the adjective.

Task: Tracey forgot _________ (to call) her grandfather. He had been waiting for that call so much but she didn't make it.
comment: Some verbs can be used both with the Gerund and the Infinitive. But in some cases the meaning of the sentence becomes different. Compare: forgot to call - forgot that she needed to call / forgot calling - she called him but she forgot that fact.

Task: Do you have an allergic reaction ___ antibiotics?
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'reaction to'.

Task: They haven't replied ___ my plea yet.
comment: It is correct to say 'to reply to something'.

Task: The Tower of Pisa is crowded ______ tourists all the year round.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'crowded with'.

Task: You can see several _____ in the Zoo.
comment: There are some nouns which have the same form in the singular and in the plural: A MOOSE - THREE MOOSE.

Task: We cannot afford a dinner in this restaurant. We have ______ dollars left.
comment: A little and 'much' are used before uncountable nouns. 'Many' and 'a few'  - before countable ones. 'Many' doesn't relate to the meaning.
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: Express disappointment with the present situation: I want to be popular. But I'm not.
a: If only I had been popular when I wanted.
b: If I were popular I would want it.
c: I would be popular if I wanted.
comment: To express disappointment with the present situation we usually use the construction [ I + wish + Past Simple]. Other answers do not relate to the meaning.

Task: Form a compound adjective from two words: slow + move
comment: We say 'slow-moving'

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: My brother finds  always a way out of any situation.
b: Always my brother finds a way out of any situation.
c: My brother finds a way out of any situation always.
d: My brother always finds a way out of any situation.
comment: The adverb goes after the auxiliary verb. But if there is no auxiliary verb in the sentence, the adverb should be placed before the main verb.

Task: I heard ___ dog barking somewhere in the slum.
comment: We use the article 'a' with singular countable nouns when we talk about them in general.

Task: The next bus ______ at 9 o'clock this morning.
comment: To talk about schedule we use Present Simple.

Task: Oh, how I wish it _____ (not to be) so windy.
comment: If we talk about wishes and refer to the future or present we use the Past Simple.

Task: I _____ (to call) you when I ______ (to come) home.
comment: To talk about the future we often use clauses with 'when, after, until'. We use the present tense inside them and future tense in the main sentence.

Task: Transfer this Active Voice sentence into the Passive one: He's fixing a laptop at the moment.
a: The laptop is being fixing at the moment.
b: The laptop is been fixed at the moment.
c: The laptop is being fixed at the moment.
d: The laptop has been fixed at the moment.
comment: Is being fixed' is the right form of the Present Progressive Passive

Task: Jillian was very disappointed that she has _______ a mistake.
comment: We say 'to make a mistake'.

Task: I'm ill and feel very weak. I have to ______ (to cancel) the meeting.
comment: Phrasal verb 'to call something off' means 'to cancel something'.

Task: Choose  two forms of the verb 'to rive' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO RIVE - RIVED - RIVEN / RIVED

Task: _________  investigators didn't find any evidence of Mr. Clark's involvement in hijacking, he was imprisoned.
comment: When we want to show a conflict between the main clause and the statement in the subordinate clause we can use 'although (and its synonyms), while, whilst or whereas'. Note that 'while' and 'whilst' are used mostly in formal contexts. Other given linking words do not relate to the meaning of the sentence.

Task: It is necessary to reduce ________ expenses in the nearest future.
comment: We should remember that the adjective 'essential' is used with the prefix 'non-'

Task: Derek, please, visit me as fast as you can! I need your help _______.
