comment: We use adverbs to describe time, degree, manner, etc. In other words adverbs help us get more information about the action or a place (where, when, how, how often, etc.)They are formed by adding '-ly' or '-ily' to the adjective.

Task: Clark agreed _______ (to tell) me the truth.
comment: Agree requires the Infinitive. We cannot use the Gerund with this verb.

Task: I have a recipe ___  paella with seafood. I can give it to you.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'recipe for'.

Task: __ avoidance of misunderstanding you should check the information attentively.
comment: It is correct to say 'in avoidance of'.

Task: Sarah should be very attentive with food. She is allergic _____ peanuts.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'allergic to'.

Task: Some peculiarities of the language should be noted in _______.
comment: There are many nouns which have Greek or Latin origin. As a rule, they keep own endings: ONE PARENTHESIS - TWO PARENTHESES

Task: How _____ questions are you going to ask in your interview?
comment: Many is used before countable nouns. 'Much' and 'a little' - before uncountable ones. We use 'any' in negative and interrogative sentences.
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: Express regret about the past: I regret that I watched that movie.
a: I wish I hadn't watched that movie.
b: I wish I didn't watch that movie.
c: I wouldn't have watched that movie.
comment: When we want to show regret about the past we usually use the construction [ I + wish + Past Perfect]. Other answers do not relate to the meaning.

Task: Use a suffix to form an adjective from a given word: efficiency
comment: We say 'efficient'

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: You easily can lose your friend's trust.
b: You can lose easily your friend's trust.
c: You can easily lose your friend's trust.
d: Easily you can lose your friend's trust.
comment: The adverb 'easily' must be placed after the auxiliary verb 'can'.

Task: The travel company made us ______ advantageous offer.
comment: We use articles 'a/an' to show the quantity - only one. 'An' is used before words starting with sounds [a], [e], [i], [o], [u]

Task: Dave _______ (to visit) his Granny every month.
comment: When we talk about things in general, permanent situations and states or things which happen sometimes, we use the Present Simple Tense:  he/she/it +  Verb + -s(es)

Task: The children ______ (to watch) 'The Hunger Games' when suddenly the light ______  (to go) out.
comment: The first action was in progress when suddenly the second one interrupted it. For a longer action we use the Past Continuous Tense. The second action was shorter so we use the Past Simple Tense

Task: Spring has come at last. It _________ (to be) sunny in several days.
comment: We use the Future Simple Tense when we talk about actions which will certainly happen in the future and which we cannot control.

Task: The novel 'The old man and the sea' _________ (to write) by Ernest Hemingway in 1951.
comment: Sometimes we need to change a sentence from the Active Voice into the Passive Voice. We can also mention a person who carries out the action. In this case we use the Passive Voice and form a sentence according to this rule:  Subject - Be+ Past Participle - Preposition 'BY' - Agent (who or what carries out the action). Also, we should use the Past Simple Passive Voice In this sentence.

Task: Mila, could you _____ me a favor? Please, don't say those words about John anymore.
comment: We say 'to do a favor'.

Task: Drake, I've ________ (to choose) four T-shirts. Which one suits me better?
comment: Phrasal verb 'to pick out' means 'to choose'.

Task: Choose  two forms of the verb 'to lie' (to be in a horizontal position) according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO LIE - LAY - LAIN. The verb 'to lie' (not to tell truth) is regular: TO LIE - LIED - LIED.

Task: _________, we all were happy to get home finally.
comment: When we want to summarise what we have said or written before we use these linking words: 'in a nutshell, to conclude, in conclusion, in brief, in summary'. Other given linking words do not relate to the meaning of the sentence.

Task: Well, I've got an idea how to transform this terrible place into a ______ cosy shelter.
comment: Lovely' means 'charming', while 'loving' means - 'feeling love', 'beloved' means - 'loved very much' and 'loveless' means - 'unloved'.

Task: It's cold outside. You have to dress up  _______ !
comment: We use adverbs to describe time, degree, manner, etc. In other words adverbs help us get more information about the action or a place (where, when, how, how often, etc.)They are formed by adding '-ly' or '-ily' to the adjective.

Task: Mrs. Burton seemed ________ (to be) happy.
comment: Seem requires the Infinitive. We cannot use the Gerund with this verb.

Task: Paul fell heir _____ his grandfather's fortune and property.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'to fall heir to'.

Task: Harry will be late for the performance _______ an extremely long traffic jam.
comment: We use 'because of' to show the reason.

Task: The dog was totally obedient ______ Mike.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'obedient to'.

Task: How many _______ (an axis) has the Earth?
comment: The noun 'axis' has the irregular plural form: AXIS - AXES

Task: That event was described in ________ Italian newspaper. I don't know its title exactly.
comment: We use 'some' in positive sentences and 'any' in negative ones before countable or uncountable nouns. 'Many' and 'a few' are used before plural countable nouns.
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: Express the idea when you want someone to do something in the present or future: I don't want you to stay there for a long time.
a: I'd rather you hadn't stayed there for a long time.
b: I'd rather you didn't stay there for a long time.
c: I wish you stay there for a long time.
d: I wish you stayed there for a long time.
comment: When we need to express the idea when you want someone to do something in the present or future we usually use the construction [would rather + subject + Past Simple]. Other answers do not relate to the meaning.

Task: Find the correct word formation chain (noun - adjective - verb): analysis
comment: We say 'analyst - analytical - analyse'

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: Yesterday it was his car that stolen.
b: That stolen car was his yesterday.
c: It was his car that was stolen yesterday.
d: It was that his car stolen yesterday.
comment: Cleft sentences with 'it' are formed in this way: it + to be + object + that. We use this structure to focus on the information that we put in the first place. Here: it's important to say 'it was his car' - not someone else's one.

Task: The US has an air base in ___ Indian ocean.
comment: The is used before names of oceans.

Task: His grandparents _______ (to be) married for 60 years.
comment: The action in this sentence started in the Past and continues in the Present. It means that his grandparents got married 60 years ago and are still married. In this case we should use the Present Perfect Tense:  has/have + Verb (-ed/Past Participle)

Task: Maria ______ (to study) at the Ontario Secondary School from 2008 to 2010
comment: We use the Past Simple Tense when we talk about actions which happened at a definite time in the past. If we have a regular form of a verb in a sentence, we add '-ed'. Irregular forms should be memorized.

Task: By next October, I __________ (to finish) the research.
comment: The Future Perfect helps to express the idea that one action will happen before another one or the certain time point in the future.

Task: The Mona Lisa ______ (to paint) in 1503-1505.
comment: When we don't know who carries out the action, or it is obvious or unimportant to us, we use the Passive voice. The Passive is formed: BE + Past Participle. In this sentence the action took place at a certain time in the past, so we use the Past Simple Passive.

Task: Pete has ______ money by selling luxury cars.
comment: We say 'to make money'.

Task: I'm not a person who can _____ (to tolerate) teenagers.
comment: Phrasal verb 'to put up with' means 'to tolerate'.

Task: Choose  two forms of the verb 'to grind' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO GRIND - GROUND - GROUND

Task: All the given plans opened for us a wide range of opportunities to release our potential. ________ they tell us about the competition and huge risks.
comment: When we want to add some extra information to the point we can use these linking words: furthermore, moreover, as well as, too, also, besides.  Other given linking words do not relate to the meaning of the sentence.

Task: I've run 10 kilometres and feel _______ exhausted.
comment: Some words can make adjectives stronger. We call these words 'intensifiers'. Some of them are: very, really, pretty, absolutely. Remember that with strong adjectives (with extreme meaning) like 'exhausted' we use certain intensifiers. For example: exceptionally, completely, absolutely, totally, utterly, quite.

Task: Darren was running as _____ as he could.
comment: It is correct to say 'as fast as'. Remember that the word 'fast' do not change its form when we use it an adverb or adjective.

Task: The newspaper reported the party _______ (to win) the election.
comment: Report requires the Gerund. In this case the Gerund is used as the object of the verb.

Task: Locals are asking the city authorities to build a fence ______ the central park.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'a fence around something'.

Task: ____ my humble opinion, the plot of this book is overextended.
comment: It is correct to say 'in somebody's opinion'.

Task: Felix is mad ____ 'Queen' and 'Slipknot'.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'mad about' in the meaning of 'being a fan of'.

Task: Scientists say that stars called supergiants have ____ (a radius) many times larger than that of our planet.
comment: There are many nouns which have Greek or Latin origin. As a rule, we memorize their forms: A RADIUS - TWO RADII. 'Radiuses' also can be used.

Task: How _____ paper do we use in the office daily?
comment: Much is used before uncountable nouns. 'Many' and 'a few'  - before countable. 'Some' do not relate to the meaning of the sentence.
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: If Drake _______ (to have) time he _______ (to study) better.
comment: When we speak about past unreal condition we use: If-clause (if + Past Perfect) - Main Clause (would have + past participle). In reality Drake didn't have time to study better.

Task: Find the correct word formation chain (noun - adjective - verb): assassination
comment: We say 'assassin - assassinated - assassinate'

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: Ashley bought a new white mink fur coat a week ago.
b: Ashley bought a white new mink fur coat a week ago.
c: Ashley bought a new mink white fur coat a week ago.
d: Ashley bought a white mink new fur coat a week ago.
comment: There is a certain word order in statements with the Present Simple Tense: Subject - Auxiliary - Object. When we need to use many adjectives in one sentence, they should be placed in the following order: Opinion - Size - Age - Shape - Colour - Origin - Material - Purpose. 'New' defines age, 'white' refers to colour and 'mink' - to material.

Task: There is ____ table and four chairs in the kitchen.
comment: We use the article 'a' with singular countable nouns  to show quantity - only one.

Task: The weather _____ (to improve). I think we can go roller skating to the park soon.
comment: We use the Present Continuous in case of changing situations

Task: In the cafe we _____(to try) some delicious food, ________ (to drink) some wine and then we ______ (to walk)a lot in the city centre.
comment: When we talk about actions which happened one after the other in the past we use the Past Simple Tense.

Task: Darrel has realised too late that he ________ (to wait) for Jill for more than 3 hours when her aircraft lands.
comment: The Future Perfect Continuous (like the Future Perfect) expresses the idea that an action will continue up until another one or certain time point in the Future. But the Future Perfect Continuous is more concentrated on the duration. We use it when it is important for us to emphasise 'how long' something will be in progress in the future: for an hour, for a week, for a year, etc.

Task: Transfer this Active Voice sentence into the Passive one: The company is still constructing the building.
b: The building is still been constructed.
c: The building is still being constructed.
d: The building is still have being constructed.
comment: We use the Present Continuous in this sentence. Therefore we should use the appropriate form of the Passive - [auxiliary] + [being] + [verb+-ed / Past Participle]

Task: Please, ______ your seats and fasten belts.
comment: We say 'to take/have a seat'.

Task: I hate job interviews because it always seems like they ______ (to look arrogantly) me.
comment: Phrasal verb 'to look down on' means 'to look arrogantly and contemptuously'.

Task: Choose  two forms of the verb 'to misunderstand' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO MISUNDERSTAND - MISUNDERSTOOD - MISUNDERSTOOD

Task: Sure, you may take my phablet ________ you don't damage it.
comment: When we want to express a condition we usually use these linking words: as long as, provided/providing (that).  Other given linking words do not relate to the meaning of the sentence.

Task: The performance was not brilliant, but I found it _______ interesting.
comment: Some words can make adjectives weaker. We call these words mitigators. Some of them are: rather, a bit, a little bit, slightly, fairly. Intensifiers like 'completely, exceptionally' are used with extreme adjectives. Remember that 'enough' goes after the adjective.

Task: I don't know what is going on! Jake _____ ignored me when I tried to talk to him.
comment: Very often we use adverbs as intensifiers. It means that they help us emphasise something. Remember that adverbs are formed by adding '-ly' or '-ily' to the adjective.

Task: Mr. Johnattan didn't mind _______ (to help) me.
comment: not to mind requires the Gerund. In this case the Gerund is used as the object of the verb.

Task: There are a lot of advantages ____ working as a stewardess.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'advantage in'.

Task: _______ all our previous troubles we've got another crashing news today.
comment: It is correct to say 'in addition to'. Other options do not relate to the meaning.

Task: Max moved into a new  place. He has to get accustomed ____ it.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'accustomed to'.

Task: The meeting of ______ (alumna) will be held on Saturday.
comment: There are many nouns which have Greek or Latin origin. As a rule, they keep own endings: A ALUMNA - TWO ALUMNAE

Task: We live a boring life. We never go ______ .
comment: We use 'some' in positive clauses while 'any' - in negative. 'Never' refers to negative meaning.
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: If Julia _____ (to be) lucky, she ______ (to be taken) on this prestigious job.
comment: When we speak about probable situations in the present or future we use Conditional 1: If-clause (if + Present Simple) - Main Clause (future/modal + present without 'to')

Task: Find the correct word formation chain (noun - adjective - verb): agitation
comment: We say 'agitator - agitated - agitate'

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: Who had been sleeping during the flight the man  woke up.
b: The man during the flight who had been sleeping woke up.
c: The man woke up who had been sleeping during the flight.
d: The man who had been sleeping during the flight woke up.
comment: The subject is normally placed before the predicate. Note, that very often the subject is not a single word. Here: 'The man who had been sleeping during the flight' - is the subject. Then, you should pay attention to the word order inside this phrase: the man - is on the first place and relative clause with 'who' follows it.

Task: The most famous carnival is celebrated in ______Brazil.
comment: The' is not used before names of countries, but there are some exceptions: the Netherlands, the Argentine, the Vatican City, the Sudan.

Task: Origami _________ (to be) his hobby since childhood.
comment: The action in this sentence started in the Past (childhood) and continues in the Present. It means that he is still fond of origami. In this case we should use the Present Perfect Tense:  has/have + Verb (-ed/Past Participle)

Task: Uma __________ (to visit) Moscow when she _____ (to be) young.
comment: We use the Past Simple Tense when we talk about actions which happened at a certain time in the past. Here: when she was young.

Task: - It's so stuffy here!  - I ______ (to open) the window.
comment: We use the Future Simple Tense when someone suggests to do something voluntarily.

Task: Unfortunately all rooms in this hostel  ____ (already / to book). We need to look for another hostel.
comment: The correct form of the Present Perfect Passive is: [have/has] + been + [verb+ -ed / Past Participle]

Task: The Sumptons went on a two-month ______ to Europe and returned to New York in September.
comment: Voyage - is a long trip, very often at sea. 'Journey' - means moving from one point to another in a vehicle (bus journey, train journey, etc.). Trip - covers the whole process (moving somewhere and back, rest, pleasure and purpose). 'Travel' - is used to talk about the activity of moving from one point to another generally (air travels has become more expensive this year)

Task: Their project ______ (is successful) very fine.
comment: Phrasal verb 'to work out' means 'to be successful '.

Task: Choose  two forms of the verb 'to quit' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO QUIT - QUIT -QUIT

Task: _____ it was sunny, we took sunglasses and a parasol to shade skin from the light.
comment: It was sunny' is the reason why we took sunglasses and a parasol. To give a reason for a certain situation we use 'seeing that, seeing as, as, because, since' + clause. Other given linking words do not relate to the meaning of the sentence.

Task: It was _______ of Laura to keep silent in response to a stranger's abuse in the subway.
comment: Sensitive', 'sentimental' and 'sensual' don't relate to the meaning of the sentence. In this sentence we speak about reasonable -'sensible' decision.

Task: _______ speaking, this song is utter garbage.
comment: It is correct to use the adverv 'bluntly'. It means 'direct manner of speaking'.

Task: This car needs _______ (to clean).
comment: Some verbs can be used both with the Gerund and the Infinitive. But in some cases the meaning of the sentence becomes different. Compare:  needs to clean - somebody has the necessity in cleaning / the car needs cleaning - the car needs to be cleaned by somebody

Task: Her memory ___ traveling in Europe will stay with her for a long time.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'memory of'.

Task: It's not polite to leave ________ saying goodbye.
comment: It is correct to say 'without saying'. Other answers are illogical.

Task: Surely he's capable ___ winning the prize.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'capable of'.

Task: They watched the performance through ______ .
comment: Some nouns are always plural: SCISSORS/GLASSES/TROUSERS/JEANS/SHORTS/TIGHTS/PYGAMAS/NEWS/BINOCULARS etc.

Task: They have finally managed to complete the project without _____ help.
comment: We use 'some' in positive sentences and 'any' in negative ones. 'Without' refers to the negative meaning. 'Many' and 'a few' do not relate to the meaning of the sentence.
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: Express disappointment with the present situation: George has to go shopping with his wife. But he doesn't want to.
a: George wishes he would go shopping with his wife.
b: George wished he hadn't gone shopping with his wife.
c: George wishes he didn't have to go shopping with his wife.
d: George wouldn't go shopping with his wife if he wanted.
comment: To express disappointment with the present situation we usually use the construction [ I + wish + Past Simple]. Other answers do not relate to the meaning.

Task: Use a suffix to form an adjective from a given word: baby
comment: We say 'babyish'

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: Hardly had Tom the house reached, it started to snow heavily.
b: Hardly Tom had reached the house, it started to snow heavily.
c: Hardly had Tom reached the house, it started to snow heavily.
d: Hardly had reached the house Tom, it started to snow heavily.
comment: If 'hardly' goes in the beginning of the sentence we should invert subject and predicate. Compare: Tom had reached (normal word order) - had Tom reached (inverted order)

Task: Do you know ____ girl who is standing next to Caroline?
comment: We use 'the' with all kinds of nouns when we talk about definite and specific things.

Task: My parents ________ (to travel) since last May and they are not at home yet.
comment: We use the Present Perfect Continuous for actions that started in the past and continue in present. By using this tense we also emphasize the process.

Task: Charlie _______ (to come) home before Andy ________ (to finish) cooking.
comment: The first action (Charlie had come home) happened earlier than the second one (Andy finished cooking). To show this sequence we use Past Perfect and Past Simple one after another.

Task: Unfortunately, the disease ________ (still / to spread) during next few months.
d: is still be going to spread
comment: We use the Future Continuous Tense to show that the action is developing in the present and that we expect it to continue in the future.

Task: Transfer this Active Voice sentence into the Passive one: Everyone believes that the rescue group will complete the work successfully.
a: The rescue group it is believed will complete the work successfully.
b: It believed that the rescue group will complete the work successfully.
c: It is believed that the rescue group will complete the work successfully.
d: It is believed that the work successfully  will complete the rescue group.
comment: The Present Simple Passive is formed: BE + Past Participle. The correct word order is represented in answer 3.

Task: The company ________ an interesting offer to us.
comment: We say 'to make an offer'

Task: Sandra always ________ (to act extra special in public) when she wears a new dress.
comment: Phrasal verb 'to show off' means 'to act extra special in public'.

Task: Choose  two forms of the verb 'to spell' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO SPELL - SPELT - SPELT

Task: ________ the traffic jams, we couldn't get there on time.
comment: Traffic jams' is the reason why we couldn't get there on time. To introduce a reason we could also use 'because'. But you should remember that after 'because' we place a clause. Linking words of reason that are followed by a noun are: owing to, due to, because of. Other given linking words do not relate to the meaning of the sentence.

Task: ______ friends are worse than enemies.
comment: We should remember that the adjective 'honest' is used with the prefix 'dis-'

Task: Peter didn't hesitate even a second. He pushed the door open ________ and went outside.
comment: When we do something 'decisively' we do not think twice. We take the decision quickly and firmly. Other options do not relate to the meaning.

Task: Brittany tried _______ (to learn) English, but she didn't succeed in it.
comment: Some verbs can be used both with the Gerund and the Infinitive. But in some cases the meaning of the sentence becomes different. Compare: she tried eating carrot jam - she experimented with the jam, but she didn't enjoy it / she tried to learn English - we start something but do not have success

Task: This task was a piece ___ cake.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'piece of'. Idiom 'to be a piece of cake' means 'to be easy to do something'.

Task: The figure skating competition is ______  now.
comment: It is correct to say 'to be underway'.

Task: Terry is sorry ____ being rude.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'sorry for'.

Task: My little niece likes _________ very much.
comment: There are some nouns which have the same form in the singular and in the plural: FRUIT - FRUIT (if we speak about it in general). But speaking about different types - we say: KINDS OF FRUITS.

Task: _____ men, _____ minds (idiom).
comment: We say 'Many men, many minds'. 'Many' is used before countable nouns. 'Much' and 'a little' - before uncountable. We use 'any' in negative and interrogative sentences.
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: Express regret about the past: We regret that we visited that museum.
b: We wish we didn't visit that museum.
c: We wish we hadn't visited that museum.
d: We wouldn't have visited that museum.
comment: When we want to show regret about the past we usually use the construction [ I + wish + Past Perfect]. Other answers do not relate to the meaning.

Task: Form a compound adjective from two words: single + storey
comment: We say 'single-storey'

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: Never before such a beautiful place had  visited Jake.
b: Never before Jake had visited such a beautiful place.
c: Never before had Jake visited such a beautiful place.
d: Never before such a beautiful place Jake had  visited.
comment: When a sentence starts with 'never before' subject and predicate (that go after it) are usually inverted. In spoken language it is possible to use option 2, but formally it is not correct. Other answers are illogical or wrong.

Task: His son plays ____cello skillfully.
comment: The is used before names of musical instruments.

Task: Paul _________ (to read) this book for over two months.
comment: We use the Present Perfect Continuous to emphasise the duration of the action.

Task: It ________ (to happen) last year. I ________ (to swim) in the sea when unexpectedly I _________ (to see) the burning ship.
b: was happening / was swimming / was seeing
comment: 1. 'last year' is a hint to use the Past Simple: happened. 2. For a longer action in the past we use the Past Continuous and for a short one - the Past Simple: was swimming / saw

Task: By the time Katie ______ (to leave) she ________ (to be) in Rome for a year.
comment: When we want to show that the action will continue up until another one in the future we use the Future Perfect.

Task: The song 'I will always love you' _________(to compose) by a singer Dolly Parton in 1974.
comment: Sometimes we need to change a sentence from the Active Voice into the Passive Voice. We can also know a person who carries out the action. In this case we use the Passive Voice and form a sentence according to this rule:  Subject - Be+ Past Participle - Preposition 'BY' - Agent (who or what carries out the action). In this sentence the action took place at a certain time in the past, so we use the Past Simple Passive.

Task: I'm so tired. I need to ______ a walk in the park.
comment: We say 'to take a walk'.

Task: ________ (to be attentive to probable risk) icicles on the roof.
comment: Phrasal verb 'to watch out for' means 'to be attentive to probable risk'.

Task: Choose  two forms of the verb 'to unsay' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO UNSAID - UNSAID

Task: Barbara stopped ________ to text Brian.
comment: To text Brian' is a purpose why Barbara stopped. When we introduce a purpose we use 'in order/so as + to-infinitive' or 'so (that)/in order (that) + clause'. Other given linking words do not relate to the meaning of the sentence.

Task: This green sofa is _____(cozy) than the yellow one.
comment: When we compare two things or two people we use the comparative form of adjectives. We add [-er / -ier] to short adjectives.

Task: Oh, God! Do you see Mike? He looks ________ ridiculous in this yellow coat.
comment: Utterly means 'extremely, totally, completely'. Other answers are not possible according to the meaning of the sentence.

Task: Drew offered _______ (to have) a rest.
comment: Offer requires the Infinitive.

Task: In answer ___ his  letter of inquiry Bill was invited to an executive session.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'in answer to'.

Task: Mary is still in the hospital. But she is  ___ high spirits.
comment: It is correct to say 'in high spirits'.

Task: This behaviour is very peculiar ____ Tim. He is a real rowdy.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'peculiar to'.

Task: Bus is a very comfortable ________ of transport.
comment: There are some nouns which have the same form in the singular and in the plural: ONE MEANS - TWO MEANS

Task: It was hard but we have done ______ of the work finally. Now we have less than a half.
comment: Many is used before countable nouns. 'Much' and 'a little' - before uncountable. 'A little' doesn't relate to the meaning. We use 'any' in interrogative and negative sentences.
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: If  Mike_______ (to have) time he _________ (can earn) more teaching  Polish in addition to his main work.
comment: When we speak about imaginary situations which differ from real facts in the present we use Conditional 2: If-clause (if + Past Simple) - Main Clause (would/could + present without 'to'). The meaning of this sentence: in reality Mike doesn't have enough time to earn additional money.

Task: Use a suffix to form a noun from a given word: refuge
comment: We say 'refugee'

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: Andrew bought a large beautiful round aquarium yesterday.
b: Andrew bought a large round beautiful aquarium yesterday.
c: Andrew bought a beautiful large round aquarium yesterday.
d: Andrew bought a round beautiful large aquarium yesterday.
comment: When we need to use many adjectives in one sentence, they should be placed in the following order: Opinion - Size - Age - Shape - Colour - Origin - Material. 'Beautiful' is an opinion adjective, 'large' is an adjective of size, 'round' - an adjective that determines shape.

Task: Brianna is ___ gifted artist. We should visit her personal exhibition.
comment: We use articles 'a/an' when we talk about jobs.

Task: This music group_______(to become) more  and more popular. It's interesting to visit their show.
comment: In this sentence we are talking about developing situation.  So, in this case we should use the Present Continuous Tense. This Tense is formed: Auxiliary (am/is/are) + Verb-ing.

Task: - I __________ (to wait) for your call for hours! - Sorry, I ________ (to watch) TV from 7 till 10 o'clock last night and simply  ________ (to forget) to call you.
comment: 1, 2. We use the Past Continuous to show that some action was in progress at a certain time in the past - was watching TV from 7 till 10 o'clock. 3. We use the Past Simple for actions which were finished in the past - forgot

Task: By next October, Jill ________ (to receive) her drivers's license.
comment: We use the Future Perfect to show that something will happen before a certain time in the future.

Task: Transfer this Active Voice sentence into the Passive one: Everyone expects him to win the race.
a: He expects to win the race.
b: He is expected to win the race.
c: He has been expected to win the race.
d: He had been expected to win the race.
comment: The construction [subject + passive + to-infinitive] is used to talk about people's opinions in general and to report an event. As the active sentence was formed with the Present Simple, we use the same tense in the passive one: [is/are + Past Participle]

Task: ___ an actor, John wants to play on stage naturally. He never misses rehearsals.
comment: Like means 'similar to'. It would mean that the speaker is not an actor. 'As an actor' means 'being an actor'.

Task: _________ (to become calm, quiet and cool off) and tell me what’s happened?
comment: Phrasal verb 'to quiet down' means 'to become calm, quiet and cool off'.

Task: Choose two forms of the verb 'to shine' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO SHINE - SHONE - SHONE

Task: Carla was inattentive _________ she had a car accident.
comment: When we talk about a result we use 'so, therefore, as a result, for this reason'. Notice that they are usually come at the beginning of the sentence but it is possible for 'so' and ' therefore' to take also a middle position. Other given linking words do not relate to the meaning of the sentence.

Task: The red car is ________ more expensive than the black one.
comment: We can use mitigators 'slightly, rather, a bit, a little bit' with comparative adjectives.

Task: The problem is _________ serious.
comment: Obviously means 'clearly understood to everyone'.

Task: Carla considered ________ (to change) her job.
comment: Consider requires the Gerund. In this case the Gerund is used as the object of the verb.

Task: We hope there will be an increase ____ salary soon.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'increase in'.

Task: Llama belongs _______ the camel family.
comment: It is correct to say 'to belong to'.

Task: It is typical ____ her to wear far-out clothes.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'typical of'.

Task: Carl lives in Sydney. He is a _______ .
comment: Sydney (city) - Sydney-sider (a person who lives in Sydney)

Task: There was hardly ______ policeman on the road.
comment: We use 'any' in questions and negative sentences. 'Hardly' refers to the negative meaning.
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: If I ______(to win) the lottery I _____(to give) all the money to charity.
comment: When we speak about probable situations in the present or future we use Conditional 1: If-clause (if + Present Simple) - Main Clause (future/modal + present without 'to')

Task: Find the correct word formation chain (noun - adjective - verb): admiration
comment: We say 'admirer - admiring - admire'

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: Monthly bonus it is unfair to give him.
b: It is unfair to give him monthly bonus again.
c: It is unfair him monthly bonus again to give .
d: To give him monthly bonus again is it unfair.
comment: In order to avoid long complex subject sentences we usually use such a structure: [it + be + noun/ adjective + to-infinitive].

Task: Let's visit ____ Philippines next summer.
comment: The is used before the names of countries in a plural form.

Task: Helga ________ (already / to write) an essay and she __________ (it / to check out) for two hours. Don't interrupt her.
a: has already been writing / has been checking it out
b: already writes / is checking it out
c: has already written / has checked it out
d: has already written / has been checking it out
comment: 1. 'Already' shows us that the action is complete and we see the result in the present. This is why the Present Perfect is an appropriate tense for the first part of the sentence. 2. 'For two hours' and 'Don't interrupt her' shows that the process (has been checking it out) is still in progress. It started in the past and continues up in the present, therefore we use the Present Perfect Continuous.

Task: Julia ___(to take) a leash and ___ (to go) out to walk her dog in the park.
comment: When we talk about actions which happened one after the other in the past we use the Past Simple Tense.

Task: Teresa ______(to see) her son's teacher tomorrow morning.
comment: If we have decided to do something or arranged to do something in the near future we use 'be going to'.

Task: Transfer this Active Voice sentence into the Passive one: Someone turned the light off.
d: The light was turned someone off.
comment: If there is a particle or a preposition after a verb in the Active Voice sentence than we do not omit it in the Passive one. The correct word order is represented in answer 2.

Task: Do not eat junk food ____ hamburgers and fizzy drinks.
comment: When we want to say 'for example' we can use 'like'.

Task: ______ (to visit informally, to look in), if you visit Munich! I'm always glad to see you.
comment: Phrasal verb 'to drop in' means 'to visit informally, to look in'.

Task: Choose  two forms of the verb 'to stink' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO STINK - STANK - STUNK

Task: Bobby can stay here _______ he keeps quiet.
comment: When we want to express a condition we usually use these linking words: as long as, provided/providing (that).  Other given linking words do not relate to the meaning of the sentence.

Task: Barbara is so __________ . She thinks that she is the best and doesn't pay attention to anyone around her.
comment: Arrogant means 'having too much sense of self-importance'.

Task: _______ , we have lost the game and it's only our fault. I've got nothing to add.
comment: Anyway is the only logically correct adverb for the sentence. We use it to show that the conversation is about to finish. By using it we return to the main idea and sum it up.

Task: Tracey forgot _________ (to lock) the door. She spent the day trying to remember that fact. So she called her neighbour to ask him to check the door.
comment: Some verbs can be used both with the Gerund and the Infinitive. But in some cases the meaning of the sentence becomes different. Compare: forgot to lock - forgot that she needed to lock / forgot locking - she locked the door but she forgot that fact.

Task: Teachers of this high school place emphasis ____ practical work.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'emphasis on'.

Task: Look! The helicopter is flying ____ us.
comment: It is correct to say 'to fly over something/somebody'.

Task: Leo is eager ____ fame since childhood.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'eager for'.

Task: This is _____. My congratulations!
comment: There are some nouns which are used only in a plural form: NEWS - NEWS

Task: Do you know Mr. Dickens? - Yes, I do, but I can't say _________ bad about him. He's so secretive.
comment: We use the pronoun 'something' to refer to things in affirmative sentences, while 'anything' — in interrogative and negative ones. 'Any' and 'some' are pronouns which don't relate to the meaning of the sentence.
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: If Tom__________ (to lead) a healthy life, he _____ (not to suffer) from pressure-surge problems.
comment: When we speak about imaginary situations which differ from real facts in the present we use Conditional 2: If-clause (if + Past Simple) - Main Clause (would/could + present without 'to'). The meaning of this sentence: in reality Tom doesn't lead healthy life so he suffers  from pressure-surge problems.

Task: Find the correct word formation chain (noun - adjective - verb): addiction
comment: We say 'addict - addictive - to become addicted'

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: I didn't like new haircut her.
b: Her new haircut like I didn't.
c: I didn't her new haircut like.
d: Her new haircut I didn't like.
comment: We can move the object to the beginning of the sentence in order to place emphasis on the certain point or idea. Here it was important for  the speaker to express his reaction to the haircut, not something else.

Task: ____ Moon goes around ____ Earth once every twenty eight days.
comment: The is used before nouns which are unique.

Task: I _____ (to try) to wake up at 8 o'clock every morning, but today I ______ (to oversleep). Now I ______ (to make) up leeway.
b: have tried / have overslept / am making
comment: 1. 'every morning' is a mark that shows us that the action is regular. So we choose the Present Simple 2. 'Today' shows us that the time period is not over, so we choose the Present Perfect. 3. 'Now' shows that the process is developing at the moment, that is why we choose the Present Continuous.

Task: Kimberly's parents ____(to divorce) when she ___ (to be) sixteen years old.
comment: We use the Past Simple Tense when we talk about actions which happened at a certain time in the past.

Task: Sandra ________ (to work) for five years for this company in October.
comment: We use the Future Perfect Continuous to concentrate on the duration of the action which may continue after the mentioned time point. Here: Sandra will probably work for the company after October. And in October she will celebrate her 5 year employee anniversary.

Task: This part of the road  ____(to repair) in three weeks.
comment: When we don't know who carries out the action, or it is obvious or unimportant to us, we use the Passive voice. In this sentence we speak about the action which will be completed in the future: Will Be + Past Participle.

Task: It is difficult but I have to _______ a decision.
comment: We say 'to make a decision' or 'to take a decision'.

Task: Paris ____ (to forget) Matt's name ____ when she made a wedding guest list.
comment: Phrasal verb 'to leave out' means 'to fail to mention, to forget'.

Task: Choose two forms of the verb 'to speed' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO SPEED - SPED - SPED

Task: _________ Andy Murray showed a massive dominance in the first two sets, he surprisingly lost the whole game.
comment: When we want to show a conflict between the main clause and the statement in the subordinate clause we can use 'although (and its synonyms), while, whilst or whereas'. Note that 'while' and 'whilst' are used mostly in formal contexts. Other given linking words do not relate to the meaning of the sentence.

Task: The journalist called the party's election tactics _______ . But unfortunately many voters trusted it.
comment: Deceitful means 'dishonest. Someone who tries to make everyone believe in what is not true'.

Task: The summer is coming, so it’s important to know how to get tanned _____ .
comment: Safely means 'free from harm or danger'.

Task: I think the team really deserves _______ (to win) the game.
comment: Deserve requires the Infinitive. We cannot use the Gerund with this verb.

Task: I  feel a need ____some changes in life.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'need for'.

Task: He got married ____ the age ___ 35.
comment: It is correct to say 'at the age of'.

Task: Mrs. Whirpool is always nice ___ us.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'nice to'.

Task: His scientific study is called 'Rare _________ (plural of phenomenon) of nature'.
comment: The noun 'phenomenon' has the irregular plural form: PHENOMENON - PHENOMENA

Task: I haven't seen my elder sister for _________ years.
comment: Many is used before plural countable nouns. 'Little' and 'much' - before uncountable nouns. 'Every' doesn't relate to the meaning.
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: Express disappointment with the present situation: Nigel has to get up early every morning. He doesn't like it.
a: Nigel wishes he didn't have to get up early every morning.
b: Nigel would get up early every morning if he liked it.
c: If only Nigel got up early every morning he would like it.
d: Nigel would like to get up early every morning if he had to.
comment: To express disappointment with the present situation we usually use the construction [ I + wish + Past Simple]. Other answers do not relate to the meaning.

Task: Use a prefix to make a word negative: perfect
comment: We say 'perfect - imperfect'

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: My uncle is a tall dark-eyed middle-aged  man.
b: My uncle is a dark-eyed tall middle-aged  man.
c: My uncle is a middle-aged tall dark-eyed man.
d: My uncle is a tall middle-aged dark-eyed man.
comment: There is a certain word order in statements with the Past Simple Tense: Subject - Verb - Object. When we need to use many adjectives in one sentence, they should be placed in the following order: Opinion - Size - Age - Shape - Colour - Origin - Material. 'Tall' is a size, 'middle-aged' - the age and 'dark-eyed' - the colour.

Task: _______ Himalayas, which are situated in South Asia, is one of the longest mountain ranges in the world.
comment: We use 'the' before mountain ranges.

Task: She ____ (to be) a nice girl. But now she _____ (to be) so rude.
comment: 1. We use the Present Simple to talk about things in general, common regular situations and behaviour. 2. Some state verbs can be used in continuous form with the change of meaning: 'she is nice' is a personal characteristic / 'she is being rude' is her behaviour at the moment.

Task: When I ______ (to come) home I _______ (to see) nobody. It ______ (to seem) like everyone _______ (to go) not less than an hour before.
b: had come / had seen / seemed / had gone
d: was coming / saw / had seemed / had gone
comment: We use the Past Simple Tense when we talk about actions which happened one after the other in the past: came - saw - seemed. 'Before' shows us that the last action happened some time earlier than actions in the first part. The Past Perfect helps us carry out this idea.

Task: My luggage is too heavy. ______ (to help / you) me, please?
comment: We use the Future Simple Tense in requests.

Task: Transfer this Active Voice sentence into the Passive one: Romans used the Colloseum for gladiatorial contests and public spectacles.
a: The Colloseum used to be for gladiatorial contests and public spectacles.
b: The Colloseum used for gladiatorial contests and public spectacles.
c: The Colloseum had been used for gladiatorial contests and public spectacles.
d: The Colloseum was used for gladiatorial contests and public spectacles.
comment: The correct form of the Past Simple Passive is performed in the answer 4. This tense is used for complete actions in the past.

Task: The team used a big tree ___ a shelter.
comment: When we describe how we use something we take 'as'. 'Like' means 'similar to something'.

Task: Hey you, Bart! Quit ______(to laze) and help me repair the gate!
comment: Phrasal verb 'to goof off' means 'do careless work, to laze'.

Task: Choose  two forms of the verb 'to arise' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO ARISE - AROSE - ARISEN

Task: _________ the weather forecasts the city was hit by huge snowstorm.
comment: When we want to show there is a surprising contrast between two statements in one sentence we use 'although, though, even though' and 'despite/in spite of + -ing/noun/pronoun'. Other given linking words do not relate to the meaning of the sentence.

Task: Alison plaited her ________ hair.
comment: There is a certain word order in sentences with two or more adjectives: OPINION-SIZE-AGE-SHAPE-COLOUR-ORIGIN-MATERIAL-TYPE. Here: long (size) wavy (shape) red (colour) hair.

Task: Fred broke a porcelain vase ________.
comment: We use adverbs to describe time, degree, manner, etc. In other words adverbs help us get more information about the action or a place (where, when, how, how often, etc.) They are formed by adding '-ly' or '-ily' to the adjective. Some forms should be memorized: accidentally.

Task: He refused ________ (to tell) me the truth.
comment: Refuse requires the Infinitive. We cannot use the Gerund with this verb.

Task: Do you know that water pollution is one of offences _____ the environment and that it is punished by law?
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'offence against'.

Task: My brother graduated ___ the university two years ago.
comment: It is correct to say 'to graduate from'.

Task: Leo is excellent ____ playing chess.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'excellent at'.

Task: Akash lives in New Delhi. He is a _______ .
comment: New Delhi (city) - Delhiite (a person who lives in New Delhi)

Task: Tara doesn’t speak French well. She knows only ____ expressions.
comment: A few is used before countable nouns. 'A little' - before uncountable nouns. 'Many' and 'a lot of' do not relate to the meaning of the sentence.
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: Express the idea when you want someone to do something in the present or future: I don't want you to to meet him anymore.
a: I'd rather you hadn't met him anymore.
b: I'd rather you didn't meet him anymore.
c: I wish you met him anymore.
d: I wish you hadn't met him anymore.
comment: When we need to express the idea when you want someone to do something in the present or future we usually use the construction [would rather + subject + Past Simple]. Other answers do not relate to the meaning.

Task: Use a suffix to form an adjective from a given word: worth
comment: We say 'worthless'

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: What the results are of your blood test?
b: What are the results of your blood test?
c: What the results of your blood test are?
d: What of your blood test are the results?
comment: When we ask a Wh-question we use the following word order: Question Word - Auxiliary - Subject - Object. 'What' is a question word, 'are' - an auxiliary verb, 'the results' - a subject, 'of your blood test' - an object.

Task: I got up early in ____morning.
comment: The is used before the words 'evening/night/morning/afternoon'.

Task: Claire _______ (to travel) to Spain last year but she _______ (never / to be) to Portugal.
comment: 1. 'Last year' shows us that the action was complete in the past, therefore we use the Past Simple. 2. We use the Present Perfect for actions which started in the past and continue up to the present. She has never travelled to Portugal - it means that she didn't visit that country in the past and this situation is still actual for the present.

Task: As soon as Jake _______ (to answer), he ________ (to realize) his mistake.
comment: We use the Past Perfect to show that one action happened before the second one. Here: at first he had answered and after that he realized that he had made a mistake.

Task: Jim's parents ________ (to buy) a car tomorrow. They have already chosen it.
comment: We use the Present Continuous to talk about future plans which have already been arranged.

Task: Transfer this Active Voice sentence into the Passive one: Millions of people around the world have already read this book.
a: This book was already been read by millions of people around the world.
b: Millions of people around the world  has already been read by this book.
c: This book has already read by millions of people around the world.
d: This book has already been read by millions of people around the world.
comment: Sometimes we need to change a sentence from the Active Voice into the Passive Voice. We can also know a person who carries out the action. In this case we use the Passive Voice and form a sentence according to this rule:  Subject - Be+ Past Participle - Preposition 'BY' - Agent (who or what carries out the action). In this sentence we use the Present Perfect Passive: has been read.

Task: Rick tries to _____ his best at work.
comment: We say 'to do best'.

Task: We have already been discussing the problem for 3 hours. I think it is time to _____ (to finish) our conference.
comment: Phrasal verb 'to wrap up' means 'to complete, finish'.

Task: Choose  two forms of the verb 'to mow' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO MOW - MOWED - MOWN

Task: Fierce hurricane has destroyed dozens of buildings in the town. _______ Sam's family has to find another place to live.
comment: When we talk about a result we use 'so, therefore, as a result, for this reason'. Notice that they are usually come at the beginning of the sentence but it is possible for 'so' and ' therefore' to take also a middle position. Other given linking words do not relate to the meaning of the sentence.

Task: To achieve success, we need to find the most ________ way to solve the problem.
comment: The adjective 'effective' means 'successful in achieving a desired result.'

Task: This politician is not a person who speaks ________ about the real economic situation in the country.
comment: The adverb 'truthfully' means that someone speaks honestly.

Task: Justin imagines ________ (to live) in London one day.
comment: Imagine requires the Gerund. In this case the Gerund is used as the object of the verb.

Task: Charlie is an optimist. He always tries to make use ____ even unpleasant situations in his life.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'use of'.

Task: Ben is going to travel ____ China from May ______  July.
comment: It is correct to say 'through China' and 'from May through July'.

Task: Mr. Brooks is thankful ____ the yearly Managers' Award.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'thankful for'.

Task: The american F-22 Raptor air superiority fighter is one of the world's most powerful _______ nowadays.
comment: There are some nouns which have the same form in the singular and in the plural: AIRCRAFT - AIRCRAFT

Task: Tim celebrates his 21st birthday in ten days. Do you have___ gift idea?
comment: Many is used before countable nouns. 'Much' and 'a little' - before uncountable. We use 'any' in interrogative and negative sentences.
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: If Sandra _____ (to take) a painkiller, she ____ (to feel) better soon.
comment: When we speak about probable situations in the present or future we use Conditional 1: If-clause (if + Present Simple) - Main Clause (future/modal + present without 'to')

Task: Find the correct word formation chain (noun - adjective - verb): achievement
comment: We say 'achiever - achieved - achieve'

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: I'm a bit late, am not I?
b: I'm, aren't I, a bit late?
c: Aren't I, I'm a bit late?
d: I'm a bit late, aren't I?
comment: We place tag questions in the end of the sentence after a comma. The tag question always starts with the auxiliary verb: aren't I? It is correct to say [aren't I] not [am not I]

Task: The Smiths went to ____ Alps to ski.
comment: The is used before names of groups of islands, states, mountain chains.

Task: In his essay, professor Nickson _______ (to admit) the existance of UFO, but _______ (to point) out the fact that we still ______ (to have) no proved evidence of their existence.
comment: The best suitable tense for this sentence is the Present Simple. It is often used when we give some kind of a review or a summary. For example, it can be a book, a movie, a theatre play, etc.

Task: By the time he ________ (to get) home, she _______ (to play) the piano for 3 hours.
comment: 1. We use the Past Simple for short complete actions in the past - he got home. 2. We often use the Past Perfect Continuous to emphasize the duration of the action which started in the past and continued up to the specific time in the past - she had been playing before he came and continued playing after.

Task: Call me at 10 o'clock tomorrow, OK? - Sorry, I won't be able to call you. I ______ (to jog).
comment: We use the Future Continuous to emphasize that the action will be in progress at the certain time point in the future.

Task: Transfer this Active voice sentence to the Passive one: They clean my car once a week.
a: I have cleaned my car once a week.
b: I get my car cleaned once a week.
c: I get my car cleaning once a week.
d: My car have been cleaned once a week by them.
comment: We use the Passive Causative to talk about services that will be done or were done for us by someone else. We form the Passive Causative with the help of two structures: [have / get + something + past participle]. According to grammar it would be correct to use answer 4, but in spoken language it's mostly common to use the Passive Causative form.

Task: This article will tell how to make your _______ around the world cheaper.
comment: Voyage - is a long trip, very often at sea. 'Journey' - means moving from one point to another in a vehicle (bus journey, train journey, etc.). Trip - covers the whole process (moving somewhere and back, rest, pleasure and purpose). 'Travel' - is used to talk about the activity of moving from one point to another generally (air travels has become more expensive this year)

Task: My boss wants me _____ the report _____(to do something again). The first one was too short and illogical as he said.
comment: Phrasal verb 'to do over' means 'to do something again'.

Task: Choose  two forms of the verb 'to slay' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO SLAY - SLEW - SLAIN

Task: We decided to stay at home, _________ the bad weather.
comment: The bad weather is the reason why we decided to stay at home. To introduce a reason we could use 'because' and 'because of'. But you should remember that after 'because' we place a clause. Linking words of reason that are followed by a noun are: owing to, due to, because of. Other given linking words do not relate to the meaning of the sentence.

Task: I like his _______ way of thinking. He always plans everything in advance and never forgets anything.
comment: Prudent means 'reasonable, arranged, thinking about the future'.

Task: Your dress goes _____ with these shoes.
comment: Elegantly means 'in a graceful, beautiful and nice manner'.

Task: Father resisted _______ (to ask) for help.
comment: Resist requires the Gerund. In this case the Gerund is used as the object of the verb.

Task: Vanessa failed the entrance exam. I feel pity ___ her.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'pity for'.

Task: My friends left 3 hours ago and they should have arrived ___ now.
comment: It is correct to say 'by now' speaking about a deadline, time-limit.

Task: This plateau is rich ____ different minerals.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'rich in'.

Task: Give me a pair of _______ , please.
comment: The noun 'scissors' is just used in a plural form: SCISSORS -SCISSORS.

Task: Would you like an apple or a banana? - It doesn't matter, ______ is good for me.
comment: Either is used to express a similarity with a statement made. Here: you can give an apple or a banana because I like them both.
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: If I ___________ (to be) Fred I _________ (to think) several times before making such a tattoo.
comment: When we speak about imaginary situations which differ from real facts in the present we use Conditional 2: If-clause (if + Past Simple) - Main Clause (would/could + present without 'to'). The meaning of this sentence: in reality Fred made a very strange tattoo.

Task: Form a compound adjective from two words: brand + new
comment: We say 'brand-new'

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: They took a kitten small black  home.
b: They took a small black  kitten home.
c: They took a  black  small kitten home.
d: Home they took home a  black  small kitten.
comment: There is a certain word order in statements: Subject - Verb - Object. When we need to use many adjectives in one sentence, they should be placed in the following order: Opinion - Size - Age - Shape - Colour - Origin - Material. 'Small' is a characteristic of size and 'black' - is a characteristic of colour.

Task: The Mona Lisa is ____  real masterpiece.
comment: We use the article 'a' with singular countable nouns when we talk about them in general. 'An' is used before words starting with sounds [a], [e], [i], [o], [u].

Task: When I _______ (to quarrel) with my sister she just _______ (to stop) talking to me. She ________ (always / to ignore) me!
a: has quarrelled / has stopped / always ignores
b: am quarrelling / stops / has always ignored
c: quarrel / has stopped / is always ignoring
comment: 1. When we talk about common, regular situations in the present we use the Present Simple: we quarrel, she stops. 2. We often use the Present Continuous to express our negative attitude to a situation: she's always ignoring me!

Task: Jake ______ (to come) home totally exhausted. He _______ (to drive) all day long.
comment: 1. We use the Past Simple for short complete actions in the past - he came home. 2. The most appropriate tense for the second part is, the Past Perfect Continuous - because we certainly want to emphasize the process, not the result.

Task: I believe that our team _____(to take) the first place in a volleyball championship tomorrow.
comment: We use the Future Simple Tense when we make predictions, talk about desires and hopes connected with the future.

Task: Transfer this Active voice sentence to the Passive one: Someone did it for me yesterday.
c: It had been done for me by someone yesterday.
d: Someone had been done for me by it yesterday.
comment: We use the Passive Causative to talk about services that will be done or were done for us by someone else. We form the Passive Causative with the help of two structures: [have / get + something + past participle]. According to grammar it would be correct to use answer 3, but in everyday language it's mostly common to use the Passive Causative form. Then, answer 1 has another meaning. Compare: I had it done - someone did it for me / I had done it - I did it myself.

Task: Honey, you are ill. ______ a medicine, please.
comment: We say 'to take a medicine'.

Task: I _____ (to cancel) my Sunday walk in the park because of the oncoming frost.
comment: Phrasal verb 'to call off' means 'to cancel, delay'.

Task: Choose  two forms of the verb 'to redo' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO REDO -REDID -REDONE

Task: We made a decision to apply to the court _______ to get a refund from the online store.
comment: To get a refund from the online store is a purpose why we took a decision to apply to the court. When we introduce a purpose we use 'in order/so as + to-infinitive' or 'so (that)/in order (that) + clause'. Other given linking words do not relate to the meaning of the sentence.

Task: I respect Mr. Smith for his ______ point of view.
comment: Impartial means 'objective'.

Task: Look! It's raining _____. Stay overnight at our place.
comment: When we talk about rain we use 'heavily'.

Task: Bart tends _______ (to be) very mean.
comment: Tend requires the Infinitive.

Task: Darwin’s Theory of Evolution  made a great impact ______the development of biology.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'impact on'.

Task: ___ times he can behave with insolence.
comment: It is correct to say 'at times'.

Task: Don't be so mean ____ your brother.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'mean to'.

Task: Police officers march to honor their fallen _______ throughout the country.
comment: The noun 'brother' in the meaning 'a fellow member' (of any party, sect, society etc) has the irregular plural form: BROTHER - BRETHREN

Task: Look! I have brought ____ for you!
comment: We use the pronoun 'something' to refer to things in affirmative sentences, while 'anything'  and 'nothing' - in negative ones. 'Some' is a pronoun that doesn't relate to the meaning of the sentence.
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: If I ____ (to find) this book, I ____(to buy) it for you.
comment: When we speak about probable situations in the present or future we use Conditional 1: If-clause (if + Present Simple) - Main Clause (future/modal + present without 'to')

Task: Use a suffix to form a noun from a given word: advertise
comment: We say 'advertisement'

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: Can Mr. Johnson be soon given a new car?
b: Can soon Mr. Johnson be given a new car?
c: Can Mr. Johnson soon be given a new car?
d: Can a new car Mr. Johnson soon be given?
comment: When we ask a question with the modal verb we place the modal in the beginning: [MODAL + SUBJECT + MAIN VERB + OBJECT]. Adverbs like «soon, yet, usually» are placed between the subject and the root verb.

Task: Kara is majoring in ______ Chemistry and ______ Physics.
comment: We do not use articles before school or academic subjects.

Task: The next bus _________ (to leave) at 7 p.m., but I _______ still (not to buy) a ticket!
comment: 1. We use the Present Simple to talk about scheduled events and habitual actions. 2. We use «still» to refer to unfinished actions, especially when we expected to finish them earlier. The Present Perfect expresses this idea completely.

Task: That red car ________ (to belong) to Jim for 3 years before he _______ (to sell) it.
comment: 1. According to the meaning it would be correct to use the Past Perfect Continuous for the first part because it is obviously important for the speaker to emphasize the duration of the process here: for 3 years. But we remember that non-continuous verbs cannot be used with '-ing'. So it is correct to choose the Past Perfect Tense. 2. We use the Past Simple for completed actions in the past.

Task: Jessica _______ (to study) for 6 years when she finally graduates.
comment: The Future Perfect Continuous (like the Future Perfect) expresses the idea that an action will continue up until another one or certain time point in the Future. But the Future Perfect Continuous is more concentrated on the duration. We use it when it is important for us to emphasise 'how long' something will be in progress in the future: for an hour, for a week, for a year, etc.

Task: Transfer this Active voice sentence to the Passive one: this company will mow the lawn for our neighbors tomorrow.
a: Our neighbors will be mowed their lawn tomorrow.
b: Our neighbors will mow their lawn tomorrow.
c: Our neighbors will have their lawn mowed tomorrow.
d: This company will have their lawn mowed by our neighbors tomorrow.
comment: We use the Causative Passive to say that some service was done / will be done for us by someone else. It is formed: [subject + causative verb + object + past participle]

Task: Barry will stay at home for a while. He has _____ the flu.
comment: We say 'to get the flu'.

Task: The fire _______ (to begin) in a two-storey building which we had been living in before.
comment: We use phrasal verb 'to break out' when something dangerous and potentially harmful suddenly begins

Task: Choose  two forms of the verb 'to shed' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO SHED -  SHED - SHED

Task: ________ Mark was going to find a new job, he decided to learn French to get a higher position.
comment: Mark was going to find a new job is the reason why he decided to learn French. To give a reason for a certain situation we use 'seeing that, seeing as, as, because, since' + clause. Other given linking words do not relate to the meaning of the sentence.

Task: Mr. Freeman works in a ____ (medical/famous/German) school.
comment: There is a certain word order in sentences with two or more adjectives: OPINION-SIZE-AGE-SHAPE-COLOUR-ORIGIN-MATERIAL-TYPE. Here: a famous (opinion) German (origin) medical (type) school.

Task: The vase was very fragile. Garry placed it down on the table _______ .
comment: Gingerly means 'carefully'.

Task: My neighbor practices _______ (to play) the guitar every day.
comment: Practice requires the Gerund. In this case the Gerund is used as the object of the verb.

Task: The store announced a huge decrease ___ prices.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'decrease in'

Task: Titanic is ____ far the most touching movie I've ever watched.
comment: It is correct to say 'by far' in the meaning of 'undoubtedly'.

Task: Never be jealous ___ someone's success. You never know it's price.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'jealous of'.

Task: John lives in Cape Town. He is a _______ .
comment: Cape Town (city) - Capetonian (a person who lives in Cape Town)

Task: Are there ___ amusement parks in the city?
comment: We use 'any' in interrogative and negative sentences. 'A lot of' and 'much' do not relate to the meaning of the sentence. 'Some' is not usually used in questions.
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: Express disappointment with the present situation: Sarah has to work 6 days a week. She doesn't like it.
a: Sarah would work 6 days a week if she liked it.
b: Sarah wishes she didn't have to work 6 days a week.
c: If only Sarah had to work 6 days a week.
d: Sarah would work 6 days a week if she had to.
comment: To express disappointment with the present situation we usually use the construction [ I + wish + Past Simple]. Other answers do not relate to the meaning.

Task: Use a prefix to make a word negative: legibility
comment: We say 'legibility - illegibility'

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: Darrel ran his schoolmate in the mall into.
b: Darrel ran his schoolmate into in the mall.
c: Darrel ran into his schoolmate in the mall.
d: Darrel into ran his schoolmate in the mall.
comment: When we use phrasal verbs we should remember that some of them are separable while others cannot be separated. 'to run into' belongs to inseparable phrasal verbs.

Task: Drake is going to move to ___ Republic of Ireland.
comment: The is used before the names of countries with 'republic', 'kingdom', 'states'.

Task: The Queen of Great Britain ______ (to live) in Buckingham Palace. I _______ (never / to see) it but I _______ (always / to dream) about it.
a: is living / have never seen / have always dreamt
b: lives / have never seen / have always dreamt
c: lives / have never seen / I'm always dreaming
d: lives / never saw / have always dreamt
comment: 1. We use the Present Simple to talk about facts and things that are generally true - we all know that the Queen of England lives in Buckingham Palace. 2. We use the Present Perfect to talk about actions that started in the past and have the connection with the moment of speaking: I didn't see the Palace in the past and still dream about it in the present.

Task: He ____ (to enter) the kitchen, ____ (to drink) a glass of juice and ___ (to turn) on the TV.
comment: When we talk about actions which happened one after the other in the past we use the Past Simple Tense.

Task: I'm hungry. - Well, I ____(to order) a pizza for you.
comment: We use the Future Simple Tense when we have no plan or decision before we speak. We make it at the time of speaking.

Task: Transfer this Active voice sentence to the Passive one: The Simpsanes ordered to repair their house after a devastating flood.
a: The Simpsanes had their house been repaired after a devastating flood.
b: The Simpsanes had their house repaired after a devastating flood.
c: The Simpsanes had repaired  their house after a devastating flood.
d: The Simpsanes had their house been repairing after a devastating flood.
comment: We use the Causative Passive to say that some service was done / will be done for us by someone else. It is formed: [subject + causative verb + object + past participle]

Task: The troupe is ________ the performance tonight.
comment: We say 'to give a performance'.

Task: Matt has ____ (to disappoint / me). He failed to keep his word.
comment: Phrasal verb 'to let down' means 'to disappoint'.

Task: Choose two forms of the verb 'to cast' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO CAST - CAST -CAST

Task: Our boss announced that _________ those employees who came late for work would have their salary deducted accordingly.
comment: Henceforth means 'from this time on'. We use this linking word to introduce a new idea that differs from something that was ordinary and habitual before.

Task: Maria's summary report is ____ (detailed) than Ted's one.
comment: When we compare two things or two people we use the comparative form of adjectives. If we have a long adjective (with two or more syllables), we add 'more' before it.

Task: I _______ hope that he will be alright soon.
comment: sincerely means 'genuinely, honestly and truly'.

Task: Brittany tried _______ (to eat) the carrot jam once, but she didn't like it.
comment: Some verbs can be used both with the Gerund and the Infinitive. But in some cases the meaning of the sentence becomes different. Compare: she tried eating carrot jam - she experimented with the jam, but she didn't enjoy it / she tried to learn English - she started but didn't succeed

Task: Our executive director warned us about a possible reduction ___ staff.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'reduction in'.

Task: _______ the difference in their ages Nina and Den are very happy with each other.
comment: It is correct to say 'despite'.

Task: I like to be surrounded _____ energetic and open-hearted people.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'surrounded by'.

Task: We don't have enough ______ in our office
comment: The noun 'postman' has the irregular plural form: POSTMAN - POSTMEN

Task: We may not finish repairs in time. We need ___ extra hands.
comment: We use 'some' in positive sentences and 'any' in negative ones before countable or uncountable nouns. 'Much' and 'a little' are used before  uncountable nouns
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: Express regret about the past: Jacob regrets that he bought that car.
a: Jacob wishes he didn't buy that car.
b: Jacob wishes he hadn't bought that car.
d: Jacob wouldn't have bought that car.
comment: When we want to show regret about the past we usually use the construction [ I + wish + Past Perfect]. Other answers do not relate to the meaning.

Task: Use a suffix to form an adjective from a given word: accident
comment: We say 'accidental'

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: Our boss is ill, so Jack is currently filling in for him.
b: Our boss is ill, so Jack is currently filling for him in.
c: Our boss is ill, so Jack is currently filling him in for.
d: Our boss is ill, so Jack is currently him filling in for.
comment: When we use phrasal verbs we should remember that some of them are separable while others cannot be separated. 'to fill in for someone' belongs to inseparable phrasal verbs.

Task: Sport plays ____valuable role in my life.
comment: We use the article 'a' to refer to a sample of something

Task: It's 10 a.m. Jake _______ (already / to have) four cups of coffee this morning. Poor thing, he _______ (to work) all night long.
a: has already had / has been working
c: had already had / had been working
d: has already had / had been working
comment: 1. We use the Present Perfect for actions which happened in an unfinished period of time - this morning. 2. We use the Past Perfect Continuous to emphasize the duration of an action which was finished in the past.

Task: Darrel ________ (to decide) on a career of a software developer when he ________ (to be) twenty four. It _____ (not / to be) difficult because he _______ (to graduate) from IT college before.
a: decided / was / wasn't / had been graduating
b: decided / had been / wasn't / had graduated
d: decided / was / hadn't been / had graduated
comment: 1. We use the Past Simple for short actions in the past and actions which happened in a completed period of time: decided / was 24 / was difficult. 2. We use the Past Perfect to show that one action happened before another one: first he had graduated from the college and then he decided on a career.

Task: I suppose that Mary _______ (to quit) the project soon.
comment: We use 'be going' and 'will' for guesses and predictions.

Task: Transfer this Active voice sentence to the Passive one: Workers installed an air conditioning system at Jeremy's house 3 days ago.
a: Jeremy installed his home air conditioning system  3 days ago.
b: Jeremy had his home air conditioning system installed 3 days ago.
c: Jeremy had his home air conditioning system been installed 3 days ago.
d: Jeremy had his home air conditioning system had installed 3 days ago.
comment: We use the Causative Passive to say that some service was done / will be done for us by someone else. It is formed: [subject + causative verb + object + past participle]

Task: British scientists have finally ______ important research.
comment: We say 'to do research'.

Task: Patrick was so loud and noisy in the morning that I had to get up and _________ (to criticize somebody angrily).
comment: Phrasal verb 'to chew out'  means 'to criticize somebody angrily' and 'to rebuke someone severely'.

Task: Choose  two forms of the verb 'to  wring' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO WRING - WRUNG - WRUNG

Task: These two vases look rather similar, _______ they are the same shape and color.
comment: Inasmuch as is used to add a comment with more details, explain something more clearly.

Task: The video of the accident was _________.
comment: Dreadful means 'terrible, shocking, awful'.

Task: Tom behaved _______ because he knew nobody of that company. It was difficult for him to start a conversation.
comment: Timidly means in a shy and fearful manner.

Task: Andrew hopes _______ (to move) to New York next year.
comment: Hope requires the Infinitive.

Task: The demand __  labour is dependent on worker's productivity: the demand will be higher if he adds much to the revenue.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'demand for'.

Task: It's sunny. Why are you carrying an umbrella? - Just __ case
comment: It is correct to say 'in case'.

Task: He is brilliant ____ public speaking.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'brilliant at something'

Task: My little sister's favourite book is 'The Magic Swan- _____' (plural of a 'goose').
comment: The noun 'goose' has the irregular plural form: GOOSE - GEESE

Task: Did Rose buy ____ dress at the shopping centre yesterday? She has nothing to wear to the disco.
comment: We use 'any' in negative and interrogative sentences and 'some' in positive statements. Other answers do not relate to the meaning.
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: If Michael _______ (to become) an artist he _____ (can / to earn) a lot of money.
comment: We use Conditional 3 to express unreal conditions and results that could happen in the past: If-clause (if + Past Perfect) - Main Clause (would/could + perfect conditional or perfect continuous conditional). The meaning of this sentence: Michael was not a an artist so he didn't earn much money
