Task: Find the correct word formation chain (noun - adjective - verb): authorization
comment: We say 'authority - authoritarian - authorize'

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: I certainly do like your idea! I'll dream up it.
b: I certainly do like your idea! I'll dream it up.
c: I certainly do like your idea! I'll up dream it.
d: I certainly do like your idea! Up I'll dream it.
comment: The majority of transitive phrasal verbs are separable. Therefore, we can place the particle before the noun objects or after them. But we should remember that if a pronoun is a direct object then the particle always goes after it: I dream it up (correct) / I dream up it (wrong).

Task: ____ Equator divides the globe into two hemispheres.
comment: The is used before nouns which are unique.

Task: Christopher ________ (to explore) the nature of our emotions in his new book. He also _______ (to give) detailed phsychological arguments to all conclusions.
comment: We use the Present Simple to talk about summaries and reviews.

Task: When Richard _______ (to come) in he ______ (to see) that Chasey (already / pack) a suitcase.
a: had come / saw / had already packed
d: had come / had seen / had already packed
comment: 1. We use the Past Simple for short completed actions in the past: came / saw. 2. We use the Past Perfect to show that one action happened before another one: first she had packed a suitcase and then he came in and saw it.

Task: By the time Chris ________ (to arrive) we ________ (to finish) watching the film.
comment: We use the Future Perfect to express the idea that one action will be completed before the second one in the future. Here: first we will stop watching the film and after that he will arrive.

Task: Transfer this Active voice sentence to the Passive one: Carol was editing an important manuscript.
a: Carol was being edited by an important manuscript.
b: An important manuscript had been edited by Carol.
c: An important manuscript was  edited by Carol.
d: An important manuscript was being edited by Carol.
comment: The Past Continuous Passive is formed: [was / were + being + Past Participle]

Task: It is important to _______ the first impression.
comment: We say 'to make an impression'.

Task: The film was so tedious that Jerry ______ (to fall asleep accidentally) during it.
comment: Phrasal verb 'to nod off' means 'to fall asleep accidentally'.

Task: Choose two forms of the verb 'to dig' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO DIG - DUG - DUG

Task: __________ that the opposition was strong, the ruling party managed to win the elections again.
comment: We use 'notwithstanding' to show contrast between parts of the sentence. We could also use here 'although, in spite of the fact that'.

Task: Homer describes the_________ customs of the Greeks in his poem 'The Odyssey'.
comment: Immemorial means 'ancient'.

Task: We all were sitting silently and waiting ________ for the news from the hospital.
comment: Patiently means in a calm and quiet manner.

Task: We planned _______ (to get) there by 6 p.m.
comment: Plan requires the Infinitive.

Task: A departure ____ normal blood pressure can cause many diseases.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'departure from'.

Task: Alex was sleeping ______ the lecture.
comment: We should use 'during' in the meaning of 'within a certain period'

Task: Tyler looks very pale. It seems he's ill ____ fever or flu.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'ill with'.

Task: Gabriela lives in Sao Paulo. She is a _______ .
comment: Sao Paolo (city) - Paulistano (a person who lives in Sao Paolo)

Task: Formal writing: _______ water is wasted.
comment: In formal writing we use 'much or plenty of'. 'Many' is used with countable nouns.
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: It's late. If our neighbor _____(not to turn) off the music in 5 minutes, I _____ (to call) the police.
comment: When we speak about probable situations in the present or future we use Conditional 1: If-clause (if + Present Simple) - Main Clause (future/modal + present without 'to')

Task: Find the correct word formation chain (noun - adjective - verb): administration
comment: We say 'administrator - administrative - administrate'

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: Billy tried an extremely unusual and weird out gear.
b: Billy tried an extremely unusual and weird gear out.
c: Billy tried out an extremely unusual and weird gear.
d: Tried Billy out an extremely unusual and weird gear.
comment: The majority of transitive phrasal verbs are separable. Therefore, we can place the particle before the noun objects or after them. But we should remember that we place the particle after the verb if the noun is a part of a long and complicated phrase: tried out an extremely unusual and weird gear (CORRECT) / tried an extremely unusual and weird gear out (WRONG)

Task: Mr. Rogers is one of _______ best engineers in our company.
comment: We use 'the' before superlative adjectives.

Task: My family ________ (to have) supper now. But _______ (to have) a high temperature at the moment and I'm too weak to join them.
comment: When we talk about things in general, permanent situations and states or things that happen sometimes, we use the Present Simple Tense. When we describe an event that is happening in the moment of speaking we use the Present Continuous. Remember that some stative verbs (feel, have, see, seem, look, etc.) can be used in continuous form but with the change in meaning. Here: has - refers to possession / is having - means 'is eating'

Task: When I ________ (to enter) the room Mike _________ (to play) the guitar. He _______ (to play) all evening and ________ (to do) nothing about the house.
a: entered / was playing / was playing / had done
b: entered / was playing / had been playing / had done
c: entered / had been playing / had been playing / did
comment: 1. We use the Past Simple for short completed actions in the past: entered the room. 2. We use the Past Continuous for interrupted actions which were in progress in the past - was playing the guitar. 3. We use the Past perfect Continuous to emphasize the duration of some action in the past - had been playing all evening. 4. We use here the Past Perfect to emphasize the result - had done nothing

Task: This time tomorrow I ________ (to cook) while Jim ________ (to clean) the car.
a: will be cooking / will be cleaning
comment: We use the Future Continuous to emphasize that the action will be in progress in the future. Here the Future Continuous shows 2 simultaneous actions.

Task: Transfer this Active voice sentence to the Passive one: When I was in Paris somebody stole jewelry and cash from my flat.
a: I was stolen jewelry and cash from my flat when I was in Paris.
b: Jewelry and cash were been stolen from my flat when I was in Paris.
c: Jewelry and cash were stolen from my flat when I was in Paris.
d: Jewelry and cash were being stolen from my flat when I was in Paris.
comment: The correct form of the Past Simple Passive is: [ was / were + Past Participle]

Task: The coach ______ us instructions.
comment: We say 'to give instructions'.

Task: Russel always supports me. He _______ (to support somebody) over my decision to move to London.
comment: Phrasal verb 'to back somebody up' means 'to support somebody'.

Task: Choose two forms of the verb 'to sting' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO STING - STUNG - STUNG

Task: Miners went on strike _______ bad working conditions.
comment: We use 'on account of' to give reasons and describe the cause. 'Bad working conditions' is the cause why miners went on strike.

Task: Everybody loves Sarah. She is a _________  person who cares, always helps and makes your day sunny.
comment: Kind-hearted means 'kind, gentle and showing sympathy'.

Task: John was just _________ grateful that all his friends bothered to read his first book.
comment: Pathetically means in a touching, moving and heartwarming manner.

Task: Charles has finally finished _______ (to write) the report.
comment: Finish requires the Gerund. In this case the Gerund is used as the object of the verb.

Task: The results ____ this study were shocking.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'result of'.

Task: Jessica is only 6 but she has already learned a few poems ___ heart.
comment: By heart means 'to memorize by rot, word for word'.

Task: He tends to be a leader who is worthy ___ respect and allegiance.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'worthy of'.

Task: My doctor recommends me to limit consumption to three ______ a day.
comment: Formally, 'coffee' is an uncountable noun and we cannot use it with '-s' ending. But there are some meanings when it is possible. For example, here: three coffees means '3 cups of coffee'.

Task: We left a glass of water on the windowsill for some days. Now ______ of water has evaporated.
comment: We use 'many, several and none' with countable nouns.
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: If Ann _____ (to wear) comfortable shoes, she _____ (not to hurt) her feet when hiking. (But she did in reality).
comment: We use past unreal conditionals to refer to actions which never happened in reality. It can be an unreal result, imagined situation or regret about what really happened in the past. Here: in reality Ann hurt her feet because of uncomfortable shoes. Now she regrets about this.

Task: Use a suffix to form an adjective from a given word: sympathy
comment: We say 'sympathetic'

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: Joshua just do without fastfood and sweets cannot.
b: Joshua just cannot fastfood and sweets do without.
c: Joshua just cannot do fastfood and sweets without.
d: Joshua just cannot do without fastfood and sweets.
comment: We should remember that there are separable and inseparable phrasal verbs. 'Do without' belongs to the group of phrasal verbs which cannot be devided.

Task: Did you know that Rachel works for ___ Guardian (newspaper)?
comment: We usually use the definite article before newspaper names.

Task: Jim  ______ (to work / usually) at the office but he _______ (to work) at home today.
comment: 1. We use the Present Simple to talk about permanent and regular situations. 2. We use the Present Continuous to refer to temporary situations in the present

Task: The service company _________ (to apologise) because we ________ (to wait) for our car for 5 hours. We ______ (to be) totally exhausted.
a: apologised / had been waiting / had been
comment: 1,3. We use the Past Simple for short actions which were finished in the past. 2. We use the Past Perfect Continuous to emphasize the duration of the action which started in the past and continued up to some moment in the past.

Task: According to the schedule, we _______ (to depart) from London at 10 o'clock in the morning and ______ (to arrive) in Oslo at 3 p.m. _______ (you / to meet) us?
a: will depart / will arrive / Are you meeting
c: will depart / will arrive / Will you meet
comment: 1,2. When we talk about scheduled events (planes, trains, etc.) we use the Present Simple. 3. When we make predictions or simple statements about the future we use the Future Simple.

Task: Transfer this Active voice sentence to the Passive one: Sandra gave Mark an apple.
a: An apple was given to Sandra by Mark.
b: Sandra was given to Mark by an apple.
c: An apple was given to Mark by Sandra.
d: An apple had been given to Mark by Sandra.
comment: Sometimes we need to change a sentence from the Active voice into the Passive voice. We can also know a person who carries out the action. In this case we form a sentence according to this word order:  Subject - Be+ Past Participle - Preposition 'BY' - Agent (who or what carries out the action). Here the Past Simple Passive should be used: was given. Other answers are illogical.

Task: My Granny has always lived in the ________ . She doesn't like big cities.
comment: Countryside - is the area outside towns. 'Wildlife' determines some area where wild animals live, plants grow, etc.

Task: Jimmy ________ (to ask people the same question) but nobody told him how to get to the park.
comment: Phrasal verb 'to ask around' means 'to ask people the same question'.

Task: Choose two forms of the verb 'to beseech' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO BESEECH - BESOUGHT / BESEECHED - BESOUGHT / BESEECHED

Task: Vets tried hard to save my puppy. He died, _______ .
comment: We use 'though' to express contrast between parts of the sentence. This linking word can be placed in the end of the statement while other words 'although, in spite of, despite, whereas, while' (they also express contrast) cannot. They are used to connect parts or in the very beginning of the sentence.

Task: This cyclist seems to be ________ . He wins the sixth race this month.
comment: Invincible means 'powerful, difficult to be defeated'.

Task: I'm not sure, but Jay is _______ in the park.
comment: When we are not sure about something we use the adverb 'probably'. Other adverbs represented in the answers express a high degree of certainty.

Task: We prepared ________ (to get) up early in the morning.
comment: Prepare requires the Infinitive.

Task: I don't understand you.  Give me at least one reason ______ your decision.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'reason for'.

Task: Ella entered the room and smiled ______ Jose.
comment: It is correct to say 'smile at somebody'

Task: My grandfather always told me to be faithful ___ the family and friends.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'faithful to'.

Task: Most of all I like cars. I've got one. ___ is my greatest passion and hobby.
comment: On rare occasions we use  gendered pronouns to express our relation to some things very emotionally. We should remember that there are 3 genders in English: feminine, masculine and neutral. The word 'car' is of feminine gender.

Task: I'm going to the supermarket to pick up food and drink. Is there _______ you need?
comment: We use 'something' to refer to things in affirmative sentences, while 'anything' in negative and interrogative ones. 'Everything' and 'nothing' do not relate to the meaning of the sentence.
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: Express disappointment with the present situation: Garry has a cat allergy.
a: Garry wouldn't have had a cat allergy.
b: Garry wishes he hadn't had a cat allergy.
c: Garry wishes he didn't have a cat allergy.
d: Garry wouldn't have a cat allergy.
comment: To express disappointment with the present situation we usually use the construction [ I + wish + Past Simple]. Other answers do not relate to the meaning.

Task: Use a prefix to make a word negative: rational
comment: We say 'irrational - irrational'

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: Kate does rarely visit the gym.
b: Kate does visit the gym rarely .
c: Does rarely Kate visit the gym.
d: Rarely does Kate visit the gym.
comment: When we want to speak in a more formal and literary way or we want to emphasize some idea in the sentence, we use the inversion. In this case the speaker wanted to point out the adverb 'rarely'. We put it in the first place. We place the auxiliary verb after the adverb 'rarely'. So the word order is: [adverb — auxiliary — subject — verb — object]

Task: ____ Eiffel Tower is one of the most famous french attractions.
comment: We use 'the' before famous monuments, buildings, museums, etc.

Task: _______ (you / ever / to be) to Italy? We _______ (to go) there two years ago and still _______ (to remember) it.
a: Have you ever been / went / are remembering
b: Have you ever been / have gone / remember
c: Have you ever been / went / remember
d: Did you ever go / went / remember
comment: 1. We use the Present Perfect to emphasise the result. Here: we do not know how many times you have visited Italy - from the past up to now. 2. We use the Past Simple to express what happened in the past - last summer, a day ago, yesterday, etc. 3. We use the Present Simple to refer to something regular

Task: Oh, I ______ (to see) an e-mail from the support service! They _______ (finally / to reply) me. I _______ (to wait) for it for 2 weeks.
c: see / have finally replied / have been waiting
d: am seeing / are finally replying / had been waiting
comment: 1. When we use 'see' in the meaning of 'ability to see with our eyes' we use it in the form of the Present Simple. 2. When we see in the present the result of the action which started in the past and continued up to the certain moment in the present we use the Present Perfect tense. 3. We use the Present Perfect Continuous to emphasize the duration of the action which started in the past and continues up to the present.

Task: _______ (you / to come) to us to celebrate the date? We ________ (to be married) for 5 years on April 3rd.
a: Do you come / will have been married
b: Will you come / will be married
c: Will you come / will have been married
d: Will you come / are going to be married
comment: 1. When we make predictions or simple statements about the future we use the Future Simple. 2. We use the Future Perfect to talk about actions which will be completed in the future up to the certain time point: when the 3rd of April comes it would mean that 5 years have passed since their wedding.

Task: Connect two sentences using the Passive voice: Thank you all for electing me as a leader of the team. It is a great honor for me.
a: Thank you all for have been electing me as a leader of the team and it is a great honor for me.
b: It is a great honor for me to be elected as a leader of the team.
c: It is a great honor for me that you have elected me as a leader of the team.
d: Electing as a leader of the team is a great honor for me.
comment: Infinitive phrases in the passive voice help us construct sentences more gracefully and rationally. We create them: [to be + Past Participle]. They can take a position of the subject, object or modifier. Here it is on the place of the object.

Task: Trisha was seasick on her first sea ________ across the Mediterranean.
comment: Voyage - is a long trip, very often at sea. 'Journey' - means moving from one point to another in a vehicle (bus journey, train journey, etc.). Trip - covers the whole process (moving somewhere and back, rest, pleasure and purpose). 'Travel' - is used to talk about the activity of moving from one point to another generally (air travels has become more expensive this year)

Task: The company _____ ___ (to stop providing) the internet in our hotel. It's a great disappointment for us all.
comment: Phrasal verb 'to cut off' means 'to stop providing'.

Task: Choose two forms of the verb 'to frostbite' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO FROSTBITE - FROSTBIT - FROSTBITTEN

Task: Animal rights groups have influenced on cosmetic companies greatly. ________ many brands have stopped testing products on animals.
comment: We use 'consequently' to talk about results and consequences. We could also use here 'so.. that, as a result, therefore'.

Task: Migrants to European countries often take ______ journeys over the sea. Sometimes they end up tragically.
comment: Perilous means 'dangerous, unsafe, hazardous'.

Task: Tell me the reason _____ you didn't call me yesterday.
comment: We use the relative adverbs to connect sentences. They also can replace a structure [preposition + which]. Here we choose 'why' because this answer is the most logically appropriate. We could also say 'for which' but this structure is more formal.

Task: We postponed _________ (to return) to the town.
comment: Return requires the Gerund. In this case the Gerund is used as the object of the verb.

Task: The topic of today's lecture is an artistic description ___  the seasons in the works by A. Pushkin.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'description of'

Task: I'm so angry that my parents decided _______ buying a dog. I want it so much!
comment: When we take a negative decision we 'decide against' something.

Task: All war veterans are worthy ____ respect.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'worthy of'.

Task: Titanic has become one of the most famous ships in history, ____  memory kept alive by numerous books, folk songs, films, exhibits, and memorials.
comment: On rare occasions we use  gendered pronouns to express our relation to some things very emotionally. We should remember that there are 3 genders in English: feminine, masculine and neutral. The word 'ship' is of feminine gender. Here we use the possessive form of the personal pronoun 'she'

Task: My husband is always busy. He never does _____ chores.
comment: We use 'some' to refer to things in affirmative sentences, while 'any' in negative and interrogative ones.  'Nothing' and 'every' do not relate to the meaning of the sentence.
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: Express disappointment with what somebody did in the past: Sandra moved to Paris a year ago.
a: If only Sandra moved to Paris a year ago.
b: I wish Sandra moved to Paris a year ago.
c: I'd rather Sandra didn't move to Paris a year ago.
d: I'd rather Sandra hadn't moved to Paris a year ago.
comment: When we need to show disappointment with what somebody did in the past we often use a construction [would rather + subject + Past Perfect]. Other answers do not relate to the meaning.

Task: Form a compound adjective from two words: good + look
comment: We say 'good-looking'

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: I would tell him everything, were in your shoes I.
b: I were in your shoes, I would tell him everything.
c: Were I in your shoes, I would tell him everything.
d: I would tell him everything, I were in your shoes.
comment: When we invert the conditional sentence and omit 'if' we place 'should, were, had' in the first place: [should / were / had + subject + object] + [result clause]

Task: ___ French make many delicious sorts of cheese.
comment: We use the definite article to refer to a whole group of people.

Task: Tom _______ (to make) phone calls to travel agencies all day long, but he ________ (still / not / to get) a suitable offer.
b: has been making / still doesn't get
d: has been making / still hasn't got
comment: 1. We use the Present Perfect Continuous to emphasize the duration of the action which started in the past and continues up to now. We use the Present Perfect to emphasize the result - still hasn't found

Task: We ________ (to walk) in the park when the rain (to start). There _______ (to be) no place to hide nearby. So we _______ (to get) cold that day.
a: were walking / had started / was / got
c: walked / were starting / was / had got
d: were walking / was starting / had been / got
comment: 1,2. To describe the situation when one action was in progress and the second one interrupted it we use two tenses: the Past Continuous for the longer action and the Past Simple for the shorter one. 3,4 We use the Past Simple to talk about short simple actions which were finished in the past.

Task: _______ (you / to finish) working when I ______ (to come) to pick you up?
c: Will you have finished / will come
comment: 1. We use the Future Perfect to talk about actions which will be completed in the future up to the certain time point. 2. When we make predictions or simple statements about the future we use the Future Simple.

Task: Connect two sentences using the Passive voice: They blame me for something unfairly. It is very offensive.
a: I blamed by them for something unfairly and it is very offensive.
b: It is very offensive that they blame me for something unfairly.
c: To be blamed for something unfairly is very offensive.
d: Unfairly blamed for something is very offensive.
comment: Infinitive phrases in the passive voice help us construct sentences more gracefully and rationally. We create them: [to be + Past Participle]. They can take a position of the subject, object or modifier. Here it is on the place of the subject. Formally, the answer 1 is also right but in common we do not say like that.

Task: The ______ can be cruel to the humanity. Devastating earthquakes or tsunamis can kill a lot of people.
comment: Countryside - is the area outside towns. 'nature' - is the world which is not created and controlled by humans. 'environment' - the surroundings or space where humans and animals live and which can be affected by human activity. 'wildlife' - plants and animals collectively

Task: We had been friends for many years but we have finally _____ ___ (to stop being friends over some time). We entered different colleges.
comment: Phrasal verb 'to grow apart' means 'to stop being friends over some time'.

Task: Choose  two forms of the verb 'to creep' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO CREEP - CREPT - CREPT

Task: Jogging gives you strength and health. _________ , it makes you energetic and peppy.
comment: We use 'moreover' to introduce details to the information given above. We could also use here 'furthermore, what is more, also'.

Task: My friend likes travelling to nice ______ places which are unknown to the majority of tourists. He always takes there magnificent photos.
comment: Quaint means 'curious, fanciful, elegant, unusual'.

Task: Danny still remembers the day ______ he first flew an aircraft.
comment: It is correct to say 'on which'. This structure is quite formal, so we could use here a relative adverb 'when'.

Task: We have arranged _______ (to meet) at 12 o'clock.
comment: Arrange requires the Infinitive.

Task: I didn't agree with Rachel's words. I took the objection __ her remarks.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'objection to'

Task: My brother rejoiced ___ hearing the news.
comment: It is correct to say 'rejoice at something'.

Task: We were disappointed ___  the hotel's service.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'disappointed with'.

Task: Britain is my Motherland. ___ will always be my favorite country in the world.
comment: On rare occasions we use  gendered pronouns to express our relation to some things very emotionally. We should remember that there are 3 genders in English: feminine, masculine and neutral. The word 'Motherland' is of feminine gender. Here we use the possessive form of the personal pronoun 'she'

Task: Marion doesn't have _______ relatives in Italy.
comment: We use 'some' to refer to things in affirmative sentences, while 'any' in negative and interrogative ones.  'Nothing' and 'every' do not relate to the meaning of the sentence.
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: If  Sophia ______ (to become) a filmmaker, she  ______ (to shoot) documentary films.
comment: When we speak about probable situations in the present or future we use Conditional 1: If-clause (if + Present Simple) - Main Clause (future/modal + present without 'to'). Here: Sophia is not a filmmaker yet, but she wishes to shoot films.

Task: Find the correct word formation chain (noun - adjective - verb): aggravation
comment: We say 'aggressor - aggravating - aggravate'

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: Was Jake's surprise such that he didn't know what to answer.
b: Such was Jake's surprise that he didn't know what to answer.
c: Was such Jake's surprise that he didn't know what to answer.
d: Jake's surprise such was that he didn't know what to answer.
comment: When we invert the sentence with 'such or so' we put them in the first place. Remember that 'such' is followed by a verb and 'so' is followed by an adjective. Such kind of inversion emphasizes the first part of the sentence and is used both in formal and informal language.

Task: There are _____ eleven players in a football team.
comment: We do not use articles before numerals.

Task: Jarrel ______ (to drive) all night long. Now he _____ (to be) totally exhausted and _____ (to want) to sleep.
c: has been driving / is being / is wanting
comment: 1. We use the Present Perfect Continuous to emphasize the duration. 2. In this meaning we do not use 'be + -ing'. 3. The verb 'want' is not used with '-ing'.

Task: They ________ (to live) in that house for 3 years. They ________ (to move) to Denver about a year ago. But their house _______ (yet / not / to sell).
a: had lived / moved / hasn't been sold yet
b: had been living / moved / hadn't been sold yet
c: had been living / had moved / hasn't been sold yet
d: had been living / moved / hasn't been sold yet
comment: 1. We use the Past Perfect Continuous to emphasize the duration of the action which started in the past and continued up to some moment in the past. 2. We use the Past Simple to talk about short simple actions which were finished in the past. Here: the Past Perfect would show that they moved before 'they had been living'. This is simply illogical. 3. We use the Present Perfect to emphasize the result of the action which started in the past and continued up to the present.

Task: This time next month Elizabeth ________ (still / to work) in Spain.
comment: We use the Future Continuous to talk about unfinished actions which will be in progress in the future.

Task: Transfer this Active voice sentence to the Passive one: I suppose that Jeremy has written this letter.
a: I am supposed that Jeremy has written this letter.
b: This letter must have written by Jeremy.
c: This letter must have been written by Jeremy.
d: I suppose that Jeremy has been written this letter.
comment: When we suppose or make a prediction we usually use the Passive Infinitives with the modal 'must'. Here we use the present perfect form of the Infinitive: [must] + [have+been+Past Participle]

Task: Smoking has a strong harmful ________  on our health.
comment: affect - is a verb that means 'to change / make a difference'. 'effect' - is 'result of some activity'. 'effectiveness' and 'efficiency' - is 'the degree of successful activity'

Task: Patrick is always ______ __(to lie about something) stories about why he comes home late!
comment: Phrasal verb 'to make up' means 'to lie about something'.

Task: Choose  two forms of the verb 'to bind' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO BIND - BOUND - BOUND

Task: Teachers should be friendly and loyal _______ .
comment: We use 'as well' to add some positive information.

Task: My colleague is a ________ man. He doesn't forgive offenses and always pays back.
comment: Revengeful means 'resentful, a person who causes harm to anyone who hurts him'.

Task: Place the adverb on the correct place in the sentence
a: Darren was eating the roast chicken greedily because he was very hungry.
b: Darren was eating greedily the roast chicken because he was very hungry.
c: Darren greedily was eating the roast chicken because he was very hungry.
d: Darren was eating the roast chicken because he was very hungry greedily.
comment: The adverb of manner should be placed either in the end of the clause or before the verb. Here we place it at the end of the clause: 'was eating the roast chicken greedily'. We could also say 'was greedily eating'.

Task: I avoid ________ (to walk) alone in the forest.
comment: Avoid requires the Gerund. In this case the Gerund is used as the object of the verb.

Task: It was reported on Monday about record rise __  foreign investments in the country.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'rise in'.

Task: My husband deals ___ car insurance.
comment: It is correct to say 'deal in'.

Task: Our team was content ___ winning the third place.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'content with'.

Task: Oh, what a lovely chicken! _____ is yellow and bright like the Sun!
comment: On rare occasions we use  gendered pronouns to express our relation to some things very emotionally. We should remember that there are 3 genders in English: feminine, masculine and neutral. The word 'chicken' is of neutral gender.

Task: There is _______ cheese in the fridge.
comment: We use 'a little' with uncountable nouns
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: Express disappointment with what somebody did in the past: Kurt left his job.
a: I wish Kurt left his job.
b: I'd rather Kurt had left his job.
c: I'd rather Kurt hadn't left his job.
d: I would like Kurt left his job.
comment: When we need to show disappointment with what somebody did in the past we often use a construction [would rather + subject + Past Perfect]. Other answers do not relate to the meaning.

Task: Use a suffix to form a noun from a given word: disturb
comment: We say 'disturbance'

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: Not until heard Bob from Jill he did believe she was alright.
b: Not until Bob heard from Jill he did believe she was alright.
c: Not until heard Bob from Jill did he believe she was alright.
d: Not until Bob heard from Jill did he believe she was alright.
comment: When we invert the sentence with 'not until, not since, only after, only when, only by' we put them in the first place. Be careful and attentive with the word order! The first part after these words is NOT inverted while the second one IS inverted: [not until + subject + verb + object] + [auxiliary + subject + verb + object]

Task: ____ Suez Canal joins____ Red Sea and ___Mediterranean Sea.
comment: We use 'the' with all kinds of nouns when we talk about definite and specific things. Here: we should use 'the' with geographical features (rivers, seas, oceans, canals, mountain ranges, groups of islands and etc.).

Task: _______ (you / to write) the report? - Yes, I _______ (just / to finish) it. I ________ (to do) it for so long.
a: Have you written / have just finished / have been doing
b: Did you write / have just finished / have been doing
c: Have you written / have just finished / have done
d: Have you written / just finish / have been doing
comment: 1,2. We use the Present Perfect to emphasize the result. 3. We use the Present Perfect Continuous to emphasize the duration of some action which started in the past and continues up to now.

Task: I ________ (to do) yoga while my dog ________ (to play) in the garden. Now I ______ (not / to see) him.
a: was doing / was playing / don't see
c: was doing / was playing / am not seeing
d: had done / was playing / don't see
comment: 1,2 'While' shows that two actions were continuing simultaneously. In this case we usually use the Past Continuous. 3. When we use 'see' in the meaning of 'ability to see with our eyes' we use it in the form of the Present Simple.

Task: _______ (you / to stay) here until we come?
comment: We use 'be going to' for intentions and plans. This expression refers to the present situation: we know the circumstances and according to them we make the intention.

Task: Transfer this Active voice sentence to the Passive one: We all thought that Sandra had been living in Dubai for 3 years.
a: Sandra was thought have been living in Dubai for 3 years.
b: Sandra was thought to have been living in Dubai for 3 years.
c: Sandra was thought that she had been living in Dubai for 3 years.
d: We were all thought that Sandra had been living in Dubai for 3 years.
comment: Passive Infinitive helps us construct sentences more gracefully and rationally. Also it is better to choose to-infinitive in order to avoid mentioning pronoun agents like 'we, they, all, everybody, etc.' Here we use the Perfect Infinitive after the reporting phrase 'was thought': [to + have+been+Past Participle]

Task: The family chose some _______ location in order to have rest away from the city noise and hurry-scurry.
comment: Discreet - means 'careful and reserved'. 'discrete' means 'distinct'. 'exterior' and 'external' mean 'outer surface of something'

Task: Rachel, could you ______ the test papers __ (to give the same thing to many people) before the students?
comment: Phrasal verb 'to pass out' means 'to give the same thing to many people'.

Task: Choose  two forms of the verb 'to alight' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO ALIGHT - ALIT/ALIGHTED - ALIT/ALIGHTED

Task: A lot of Europeans would like to visit Japan. _______ , such a travel is very expensive.
comment: We use 'however' to express contrast between parts of the sentence. We could also use here 'though, but'.

Task: A big disappointment was Jenny Richardson's outfit. The celebrity wore a ______ dress. Fashion critics were not impressed.
comment: Flimsy means 'poor, trivial, unconvincing'.

Task: Place the adverb on the correct place in the sentence
a: The team moved after slowly we had passed more than 15 miles.
b: The team moved after we had passed more than 15 miles slowly.
c: The team slowly moved after we had passed more than 15 miles.
d: The team moved slowly after we had passed more than 15 miles.
comment: The adverb of manner should be placed after intransitive verbs which do not have an object.

Task: My little sister pretended _______ (to be) a rabbit.
comment: Pretend requires the Infinitive.

Task: Our boss took credit ____ the work our department did.
comment: We use preposition 'for' after the noun 'credit' in the idiom: 'to take credit for'.

Task: Robert excels ___ playing lawn tennis.
comment: It is correct to say 'excel at'.

Task: Some of my colleagues are accustomed ___ smoking in the office.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'accustomed to'.

Task: Aja is from Denmark. She is a _______ .
comment: Denmark (noun, country) - Danish (adjective) - a Dane (noun, nationality)

Task: There are _______ bananas left. This is not enough for us.
comment: We use 'a few' with countable nouns
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: If Grace ________ (to have) time, she ________ (to travel) more.
comment: The Past Unreal Conditional refers to imaginary situations in the past. It helps us describe how something would have happened if circumstances had been different. Here: Grace didn't have time to travel.

Task: Use a suffix to form an adjective from a given word: humour
comment: We say 'humourous'

Task: Choose the sentence with the right word order
a: Was so beautiful the weather that we decided to have a rest in the park.
b: So beautiful was the weather that we decided to have a rest in the park.
c: So beautiful the weather was that we decided to have a rest in the park.
d: So beautiful was the weather that did we decide to have a rest in the park.
comment: When we invert the sentence with 'so + adjective … that' we invert only the first part of the sentence: [so + adjective + auxiliary + subject + that] + [clause with the normal word order]

Task: __ Times Square  is very colorful in the evening.
comment: Articles are not used before names of squares.

Task: I _______ (to think) the dinner is fine. Why ______ (you / keep) silence? What ______ (to think) about?
a: think / do you keep / are you thinking
c: think / are you keeping / are you thinking
d: am thinking / are you keeping /  think
comment: 1. When we use 'think' to express our opinion we use it as a stative verb. 2. We use the Present Continuous to refer to actions which happen at the time of speaking. 3. When we use 'think' to refer to what we consider and have in mind at the moment of speaking we use it as a dynamic verb.

Task: John ________ (to spend) 3 years in Pakistan before he _______ (to become) a teacher of Urdu.
comment: To show that one action happened before another one in the past we use two tenses: the Past Perfect for the action which took place at first and the Past Simple for the one which took place after.

Task: I don't care what it means to you but you ______ (to throw) this old table away now.
comment: We use 'be to' to express strong obligation in the future. This construction is very similar to the meaning of 'must'.

Task: Transfer this Active voice sentence to the Passive one: They reported that Mr. Jacobson was playing football at that time.
a: Mr. Jacobson was reported to be played football at that time.
b: They reported that Mr. Jacobson had been playing football at that time.
c: Mr. Jacobson was reported was playing football at that time.
d: Mr. Jacobson was reported to be playing football at that time.
comment: Passive Infinitive helps us construct sentences more gracefully and rationally. Also it is better to choose to-infinitive in order to avoid mentioning pronoun agents like 'we, they, all, everybody, etc.' Here we use the Continuous Infinitive after the reporting phrase 'was reported': [to + be+ verb+ing]

Task: The politician _______ a final speech of his career.
comment: We say 'to make a speech'.

Task: My brother ______ __ (to resemble somebody from the family) our Grandpa. They both are stubborn and never give up.
comment: Phrasal verb 'to take after' means 'to resemble somebody from the family'.

Task: Choose two forms of the verb 'to fling' according to the order: Past Simple - Past Participle
comment: TO FLING - FLUNG - FLUNG

Task: ________ of going to the park, we went to the museum.
comment: We use 'instead' to express substitution or alternative.

Task: My sister chose a _______ pencil skirt and pale green top for her first date with Tom. She didn't want to look showy.
comment: demure means 'modest, discreet, shy, reserved'.

Task: Clark _______ suggested that each member of the team should take the responsibility for results.
comment: Sensibly describes something chosen in accordance with prudence and wisdom.

Task: Andrew wasted time _______ (to play) games online all the day long.
comment: Waste requires the Gerund.

Task: The newspaper's report ___ choosing the most convenient place for living was not well researched.
comment: We should remember that some nouns are used with specific prepositions after them: 'research on'.

Task: The club succeeded ___ winning the championship.
comment: It is correct to say 'succeed in'.

Task: Jake was totally discouraged ___ not winning the race.
comment: We should remember that some adjectives are used with specific prepositions after them: 'discouraged by'.

Task: Dirk is from Holland. He is a _______ .
comment: Holland (noun, country) - Dutch (adjective) - a Dutchman / Dutchwoman (noun, nationality)

Task: Sammy could see _______ because of the rain. The road was becoming more and more dangerous.
comment: We use 'little' with verbs which are not followed by a noun
topic: some,any, a lot of , many , much ,etc..

Task: Express disappointment with the present situation: Paul wants to have a million dollars. But he hasn't got it.
a: Paul wishes he had a million dollars.
b: Paul would have a million dollars.
c: If Paul had a million dollars.
d: Paul wished he had had a million dollars.
comment: To express disappointment with the present situation we usually use the construction [ I + wish + Past Simple]. Other answers do not relate to the meaning.

Task: Find the correct word formation chain (noun - adjective - verb): advice
comment: We say 'adviser - advisory - advise'
